NBC By Kate Beckman May 30, 2017 From customers dressed in bizarre costumes to incidents involving bodily functions, Walmart workers â€” like their counterparts at Target â€” have to deal with some pretty WTF moments. Here, employees shared some of their craziest stories on condition of anonymity. 1. There was a man using the hose we use to water our plants showering naked in the parking lot. He had put up a sheet to block one side, but people could still see everything. When the manager told him to leave, he acted like there was nothing weird about it. He was extremely nonchalant, like he did this all the time, and he just packed up his sheet, got in his car and left. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 2. A lady came in with coupons that she clearly photocopied, and tried to use them to get majorly reduced prices on products like laundry detergent or paper towels. She got away with it because we had a new cashier, and with all of the coupons she used and the amount of money she saved on each item, the store ended up owing her money on what would have been a $600 purchase. 3. A customer was buying some iced tea and it rang up for $4.68. She started arguing with me, saying that it was $3.33. I went back to where the tea was to check the signs, and it clearly said $4.68. I came back to tell her it rang up at the correct price, and she goes to see for herself. Then she accused us of changing the prices while she was in line and started yelling about how weâ€™re liars and stupid, and sheâ€™s going to call Walmart customer service to complain. The funny thing is, the price tags have the dates they were printed on them so she [should] have seen we were telling the truth. 4. There was a group of two guys and three girls. They were in the kidâ€™s section, and the girls were throwing these big bouncy balls over the shelves to the other side trying to hit the boys, who were riding bikes down the aisle. Then they grabbed skateboards and were riding them around the store throwing random things into customersâ€™ carts. They wouldnâ€™t stop, so we had to call the cops to escort them out. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 5. The maintenance guy was cleaning the bathroom near the back of the store, and a woman asked him to stop mopping so she could use the bathroom. He told her he couldnâ€™t let her in because the floor was wet, but she could use the bathroom near the front of the store. She went to the infantâ€™s clothing department and peed and pooped on the floor. She also managed to hide her face from the camera the entire time, so we couldnâ€™t even identify her to press charges. 6. I was working register around 11:30 at night. I gave a lady her change and she threw it on the floor. I ask her why she threw it on the floor, and she told me she wanted any children in the store to pick it up. I told her that there are no children around because itâ€™s so late, and that maintenance would clean it up anyways. She told me to leave it on the ground. 7. A woman came to guest services saying she wanted to return a basket because it was haunted. I asked her what she meant, and she said her boyfriend took a picture of it and there was electrical frequency surrounding it and she couldnâ€™t keep it in her house. She had the receipt so she was able to return it, but I still donâ€™t understand how a basket could be haunted. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 8. I was working at the service desk and a woman rushes up and says she needs to talk to my manager. I sometimes can fix the problem, so I asked her what she needed help with. Then she started yelling at me at the top of her lungs saying that the bathroom was closed and she peed on herself because it was closed. I explained that there was another bathroom in a different part of the store that was open. In the middle of me explaining that, she runs out of the store before I could get my manager, and I never saw her again. 9. Thereâ€™s a guy who comes into the store regularly and always has a beer can suctioned to his forehead. We found out itâ€™s some kind of advertising for a company, but itâ€™s still pretty weird to see him walking around the store like that. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 10. A man came into the store wearing a clown outfit and gory clown makeup. It was around Halloween so he probably worked at a haunted house, but it was pretty scary. He was just walking around, shopping for his dinner. 11. When I first started as a cashier, I was always at the register near one of the bathrooms. People would always come to me and tell me that maintenance needed to go to the bathroom, because someone wrote on the wall in poop. It weirdly was a semi-regular occurrence. Iâ€™m not sure if it was one person coming back or multiple people, but it stopped after a few months. 12. I was working the checkout line, and Iâ€™m not sure if one woman cut another one in line or bumped her with her cart, but these two women start arguing. Both of them had their pre-teen children with them. It ended with one woman telling the other that she hoped she got in a car accident on her way home. 13. A guy came into the store in a full gorilla suit. He was just doing his shopping like normal. At some point, we asked him to take the mask off for security reasons. He did, and just continued his shopping. 14. I saw a grown man walking around the store one night wearing one-piece purple pajamas with cartoon characters on it. He was probably in his late 30s or early 40s. A group of teenagers was laughing at him as he walked around, but he seemed pretty unfazed. 15. Not many customers realize that Walmart does price matching. One customer totally went to the extreme and designed his own ads with extremely discounted prices on name brands. I would have totally bought it, but the prices were ridiculous. For example, Tide laundry detergent usually goes between $9-$12 and this person had it down to $3. I played it off like everything was cool and called my manager. Next thing you know, this person is calling me every name in the book, threatening to sue me, and he literally called the police on me. Once the police arrived, my manager and I explained the situation to them and ended up having the customer sign a 'No trespassing on premises' form to avoid any more scenes with him. He ended up getting escorted out of the building by the cops. Funny thing is, I saw him at another store doing the same exact thing but with coupons. Follow Kate on Twitter. Top News U.S. News World News Voices Entertainment Movies Music TV Odd News Defense Energy Sports Fantasy Football NFL NBA MLB NHL Golf Tennis College Football College Basketball Science Health Photos Latest Photos 2016 Olympics News Entertainment Sports Features Archives Archive The Almanac Search Home / Odd News Black bear spotted wandering outside Kentucky Walmart By Daniel Uria Â Â |Â Â  May 30, 2017 at 4:47 PM Follow @oddnewsupi Comments May 30 (UPI) -- A crowd gathered outside a Kentucky Walmart early Monday morning after shoppers spotted a bear wandering in the parking lot. Witnesses spotted the black bear outside the Somerset store at around 1:30 a.m., and called police and Kentucky Fish and Wildlife officials to help remove it. "We seen it running down the sidewalk in front of the outdoor living center outside of Walmart, and me and six other cars tried to keep the bear from going towards the customer entrance," customer Malcolm Stephens told LEX 18. Avid hunters Tyler and Travis Smith captured footage of the bear while maintaining a safe distance, but said a large crowd eventually formed around the animal. "They realized what was going on, everyone walked over here and saw that there was a bear and it drew a huge crowd of people. I bet there [were]...70 or 80 people standing around with their phones out, cameras, pictures, videos, and the bear showed no fear whatsoever and laid there like a dog would," Tyler Smith said. Officials used their sirens to scare the bear into a safe area. They believe the animal eventually made its way back into the woods. Amazon stock hit 1,001.20 shortly after Tuesdayâ€™s opening bell, up about 40% from a year ago and more than 2X the 15% gainer of the S&P 500 Index in the same frame. Investors are thinking about how much further Amazon can grow as it tries to replicate its US success abroad. The 1,000 share price also puts Amazonâ€™s market value at about $478-B, 2X that of rival Wal-Mart (NYSE:WMT) and more than 15X the size of Target (NYSE:TGT). The shares will likely push even higher since Amazon is growing so quickly in massive global industries that show no signs of slowing, as shopping habits change and businesses rethink how they deploy technology, said an analyst at Cowen, who recently upped his Amazon price target to 1,125 a share. Amazon has come a long way since its start in Y 1995, when it mostly sold books. The Seattle company now sells just about anything, from groceries to small appliances, and has been blamed for taking business away from department stores, supermarkets and clothing retailers. Amazonâ€™s ventures far beyond online retail, from cloud computing to movie making, are raising questions among corporate strategy experts about its focus. The company wowed Wall Street recently with a 23% jump in sales, pushing its shares to an all-time high. But there are concerns that if blockbuster growth stops, investors may come to regard the company more like a conglomerate stock, usually worth less than the sum of its pieces. Investors also put more value in Amazonâ€™s web traffic and delivery network than they do in Wal-Martâ€™s vast store presence because online spending will grow more than 4X faster than overall retail spending this year as shoppers continue to shift from stores to websites. The worldâ€™s largest online retailer is dominating e-Commerce with its $99-a-year Amazon Prime subscription, which includes delivery discounts, music and video streaming and photo storage that keep shoppers engaged with the website. Amazon had 80-M Prime subscribers in the US as of 31 March, an increase of 38% from a year earlier, according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners. Prime memberships help lock in loyalty, which is critical as competitors such as Wal-Mart enhance their e-Commerce offerings to slow Amazonâ€™s momentum. Amazon has been tackling retail one category at a time, disrupting bookstores and electronics stores first and more recently pushing into apparel and groceries. Its rise has coincided with the decline of prominent retail chains such as Macyâ€™s Inc. (NYSE:M) and Sears Holdings Corp., which have shuttered stores and laid off workers in response to declining sales. Amazonâ€™s rise has made its founding CEO Jeff Bezos the worldâ€™s 2nd wealthiest person, behind only Microsoft Corp. (NASDAQ:MSFT) co-Founder Bill Gates, according to the Billionaires Index. â€œConsumers always want things at lower prices delivered faster. Amazon uses data better than anyone to achieve those goals for everything it sells. They have a chance to be the most dominant company in the world,â€ said on shareholder. Photo: / New Milford Police Department Facebook Page New Milford police ask for help to find suspect 1Â /Â 2 Back to Gallery NEW MILFORD â€” Police are asking for the publicâ€™s help to find a woman suspected of opening a Walmart credit card under someone elseâ€™s name. The New Milford Police Department posted on its Facebook page a picture of a woman authorities believe opened a Walmart credit card using another personâ€™s name and social security number. The suspect, police said, has not made any substantial purchases with the card since opening it on May 6. The woman in the photo appears to have dark, short hair and glasses. Anyone who can identify the woman is encouraged to contact Officer Hayes at 860-355-3133, the anonymous TIPS line at 860-355-2000 or email/text TIPS@newmilfordpolice.org. autoevolution cars moto news car reviews spyshots driven cars newspaper green Compare Cars BAC Calculator Â  Editorial Coverstory Motorsport Testdrives archive Auto Shows Tuning Car Finder Photo of the Day Glossary of automotive terms Masthead RSS Feeds Woman Arrested After Allegedly Locking Two Kids In the Trunk To Go Shopping Â  30 May 2017, 14:18 UTC Â· by Sebastian Toma / Home / News / U-turn A shaking vehicle in the parking lot will attract attention, but things get concerning when you hear voices from it without seeing anyone in the passenger compartment. Shoppers at a Wal-Mart in Riverdale, Utah, noticed that something was wrong with a car that was parked on the lot, and a few of them came closer to investigate the matter. It did not take long to realize that two kids were apparently locked in the trunk. If leaving pets or children in the backseat of an automobile during extreme temperatures is dangerous, placing any living being in the trunk is insane. The action would not even be fun as a prank between friends, as someone could suffer from a panic attack or just die because of heat stroke or freeze to death if locked in the luggage compartment. We did not even mention getting asphyxiated, which is also a possibility in extreme conditions. According to Deseret News, the woman went shopping at the store nearby and faced the officers waiting by the unspecified car after her daughter was instructed to pull the safety latch of the trunk. The police were called by a witness who remained nameless, and he or she claimed seeing the 39-year-old locking two kids in the trunk. It is unclear if the statement reflects reality, or if the children, aged two and five, managed to enter the luggage compartment after being left on the back seats. Most hatchbacks, sedans, and wagons have a mechanism that makes it easy to fold the backrests of the rear seats to access the trunk, and it would not be impossible for a curious five-year-old to open the said compartment. However, if there is a credible witness that claims that the mother did put her kids in the trunk, things are entirely different from a legal and moral standpoint. Even if her kids managed to enter the trunk themselves, the woman is still at blame, because it is not wise to lock living beings in a vehicle. heatstroke hot cars negligence USA Utah Â  An Ode to Embracing the Metric System DIY: How to Setup An Email Address In a BMW - An Easy Guide Five Heaviest Convertible Sports Cars Available In Europe in 2017 The End of Sedans is Nigh! Amazon shares hit $1,001.20 in New York on May 30, up about 40% from a year ago and more than double the 15% gain of the S&P 500 Index in the same period. Investors are thinking about how much further Amazon can grow as it tries to replicate its U.S. success abroad. The shares will likely push even higher since Amazon is growing so quickly in massive global industries that show no signs of slowing, as shopping habits change and businesses rethink how they deploy technology, said John Blackledge, an analyst at Cowen and Co., who recently upped his Amazon price target to $1,125 a share. "Thereâ€™s a long runway there," he said. "The markets Amazon is playing in with global retail and cloud computing are just massive. Things continue to go well and investors are looking for more upside." RELATED: Amazon's delivery-drone research focuses on avoiding birds The Seattle companyâ€™s $478 billion market value is double that of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. even though the worldâ€™s biggest retailer will have sales three times larger than Amazonâ€™s this year. Investors put more value in Amazonâ€™s web traffic and delivery network than they do in Wal-Martâ€™s vast store presence because online spending will grow more than four times faster than overall retail spending this year as shoppers continue to shift from stores to websites, according to eMarketer Inc. The worldâ€™s largest online retailer is dominating e-commerce with its $99-a-year Amazon Prime subscription, which includes delivery discounts, music and video streaming and photo storage that keep shoppers engaged with the website. RELATED: Amazonâ€™s warehouse robot war is spreading Seattle-based Amazon had 80 million Prime subscribers in the United States as of March 31, an increase of 38% from a year earlier, according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners. Prime memberships help lock in loyalty, which is critical as competitors such as Wal-Mart enhance their e-commerce offerings to slow Amazonâ€™s momentum. Amazon has been tackling retail one category at a time, disrupting bookstores and electronics stores first and more recently pushing into apparel and groceries. Its rise has coincided with the decline of prominent retail chains such as Macyâ€™s Inc. and Sears Holdings Corp., which have shuttered stores and laid off workers in response to declining sales. Shopping malls have resorted to hosting concerts and carnivals in empty parking lots to keep customers coming. RELATED: Analysis - will Amazon revolutionize shipping? Another Amazon advantage is its profitable and fast-growing cloud-computing division Amazon Web Services, which maintains a global network of data centers and rents out storage space and computing functions to clients in a variety of industries, including Netflix Inc. and Airbnb Inc. as well as Capital One Financial Corp. and the federal government. Yelp runs many of its functions on AWS. This year, companies around the world will funnel $246.8 billion into Amazon and other cloud services providers, according to Gartner, up 18% from 2016. Amazonâ€™s rise has made its founding CEO Jeff Bezos the worldâ€™s second wealthiest person, behind only Microsoft Corp. co-founder Bill Gates, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. His ascendancy has won praise from fellow self-made billionaires Warren Buffett and Mark Cuban, owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team and judge on the television show "Shark Tank." â€œAmazon is worth far more than $1,000 a share,â€ said Cuban, an Amazon investor. â€œConsumers always want things at lower prices delivered faster. Amazon uses data better than anyone to achieve those goals for everything it sells. They have a chance to be the most dominant company in the world.â€ By Spencer Soper Bloomberg News Follow Transport Topics on RSS Twitter Facebook Â© 2017, Transport Topics, American Trucking Associations Inc. Box 964, Chiloquin, OR 97624 â† Private security firm compared DAPL protesters to â€˜jihadist insurgencyâ€™ â€“ leaked documents Australian paedophiles face international travel ban â†’ Nationâ€™s Top Grocery Stores Get â€˜Dâ€™ Grade on Antibiotic-Free Chicken, Says NRDC Posted on May 30, 2017 by Joe from MassPrivateI Organic Authority â€“ by Emily Monaco The Natural Resources Defense Council has assigned a â€œDâ€ grade to Americaâ€™s top five grocery store chains for their progress â€“ or lack thereof â€“ onÂ the promotion ofÂ better antibiotic practices and antibiotic-free chicken offerings. The NRDCâ€™s newÂ report, entitled â€œCrying Fowl: Major Grocers Stumble in Promoting Antibiotic Stewardship in Retail Chicken,â€ was released yesterday and investigates if and how Costco, Albertsonâ€™s/Safeway, Publix, Walmart, and Kroger market and sell antibiotic-free chicken brands. Â  These five chainsÂ represent more than 50 percent of the market share in North America.Â Overall scores attributed to each ofÂ the retailers in the report were as follows: CostcoÂ (40%), Albertsonâ€™s/SafewayÂ (39%), Publix (38%),Â WalmartÂ (38%), andÂ KrogerÂ (33%). â€œThe grades reflect the fact that none of the top five retailers have made a strong public commitment to addressing antibiotic overuse in the supply chains for chicken sold in their stores,â€ notes a news release for the Natural Resources Defense Council. â€œThe top five grocery store chains in the country feed millions of Americans, so their actions have a big impact on public health â€” for better or worse,â€ said Carmen Cordova, staff scientist with the NRDC. â€œSupermarkets can either continue to ignore the spread of drug-resistant infections, or they can answer their customersâ€™ call to be a part of the solution.â€ While this is certainly a hurdle to overcome, many retailers and restaurants in the United States have committed to addressing antibiotic overuse in livestock, particularly in recent months. Whole Foods, for example, hasÂ a storewide policy for antibiotic-free meat, and several fast food restaurants including KFC, McDonaldâ€™s, Burger King, Jack in the Box, and Subway have committed to move toward antibiotic-freeÂ chicken over the next few months or years. â€œIn the absence of action at the federal level, consumers have been driving the move toward meat raised with responsible antibiotics use,â€ said Cordova. â€œThe fast food industry has been leading the wayâ€”but people want to be able to eat better meat at home too. Our report shows that grocery stores have a lot of catching up to do.â€ More than 70 percent of medically important antibiotics sold in the United States are destined for livestock use. In an overwhelming majority of theseÂ cases, antibiotics are distributed in regular low doses to promote fast growth of animalsÂ and prevent, rather than cure, diseases brought about by unsanitary living conditions. This practice promotes the development of dangerous antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which can be extremely harmful to both humans and animals. Jump to Navigation SEARCH Search form Search â—€ Environment / Food Environment Food Fracking Water Economy Economy Labor Local Education Rights Human Rights LGBTQ Immigration Media / Culture Media Culture Books Documentaries Health Drugs Activism Belief Pleasure Sex & Relationships Food Why Whole Foods Represents the Failures of 'Conscious Capitalism' Even the best-intentioned businesses run up against the implacable foes of profit and competition. By Nicole Aschoff / The Guardian May 29, 2017 Print Comments Photo Credit: Wikimedia Itâ€™s hard to think of a better poster child for â€œconscious capitalismâ€ thanÂ Whole FoodsÂ Market, the high-end grocery store that made a name for itself selling organic produce in feel-good, mood-lit stores. These days, the chain is floundering and a potential buyout is on the horizon. What does that say about the conscious capitalism it championed?Â  Same-store sales have declined for six straight quarters, and Barclay analyst Karen Short estimates thatÂ 14 million Whole Foods customersÂ walked away during the same period. Last month activist hedge fund Jana PartnersÂ swooped in,Â buying up 8.3% of the companyâ€™s shares and demanding an overhaul. Whole Foods responded by reshuffling its board, bringing in a handful of big box retail stars and promoting Gabrielle Sulzberger, who hails from private equity, to chairwoman. A failing firm isnâ€™t exactly news. In the dog-eat-dog world of global capitalism lots of companies have their moment in the sun only to crash and burn a few years later.Â But Whole Foods was supposed to be different.Â  John Mackey, the companyâ€™s chief executive, has long argued that Whole Foods is wired differently â€” that it runs on a â€œconscious capitalismâ€ model that outsmarts the competitive pressures of our for-profit system through creativity and innovation.Â  In his book,Â Liberating the Heroic Spirit of Business: Conscious Capitalism, Mackey argues that his conscious capitalism model achieves success by honoring not just shareholders, but all stakeholders, including workers, communities, and the environment. The Whole Foods founder penned his treatise in response to the growing consensus that capitalism is doing irreparable harm to the planet and the people who live on it. Our for-profit system is increasingly viewed as a zero sum game in which ecological destruction, climate change, and rising inequality are firmly linked to the rapacious behavior of multi-national corporations. Mackey agrees that humans are harming the planet, but he doesnâ€™t think the problem lies in capitalism. Free market capitalism, according to Mackey, is actually a â€œbeautiful,â€ â€œheroic,â€ system that, properly harnessed, can operate â€œin harmony with the fundamentals of human natureâ€ and the planet.Â  We donâ€™t need to rein in corporations through onerous labor and environmental regulations, he writes, because the virtuous feedback loop of honoring stakeholders plus innovation will leave â€œunconsciousâ€ firms like Walmart in the dust. The conscious capitalism model is appealing. Itâ€™s simple, easy. We can avert looming environmental catastrophe by becoming conscious consumers who frequent conscious companies. After all, shopping at Whole Foods is a heck of a lot more fun than lobbying for regulations on corporations or convincing people to consume less. More Whole Foods, less Walmart. Problem solved. Mackey was right about one thing. People do love to shop at Whole Foods, or at least they used to. These days that demon called competition has caught up with the Austin-based company. Behemoths like Kroger, Safeway, Target, and even Walmart now offer a wide-range of organic produce for considerably less than â€œWhole Paycheck.â€ Mackeyâ€™s conscious company has gone from Wall Street darling to Wall Street basket case in the blink of an eye. The future of conscious capitalism appears equally bleak. To placate shareholders and mitigate declining same-store sales, last year the company jettisoned its unique purchasing model that wove together a network of autonomous regional production hubs of small farmers and mom-and-pop food startups.Â  Itâ€™s now prioritizing a centralized, bulk-buying strategy that looks a lot like, well, Walmart. It also initiated aÂ $1.25bn share buybackÂ program and has promised to cut costs by $300 million and raise same-store sales 2% by 2020. But according to its 13D filing, Jana Partners â€” whose founder and fund manager Barry Rosenstein recently bought the most expensive home in America â€” wants even more. Like Whole Foods, Jana is experiencing a slump, suffering negative returns in 12 of the last 19 months; itâ€™s expecting to cash in on its investment in the organics chain. A potential forced sale, most likely to private equity investors known for slash and burn tactics, remains on the near-term horizon. The point of this dour appraisal is not to crow over Whole Foodsâ€™ misfortune. Itâ€™s to take a hard look at models that claim to solve the ills of capitalism without challenging the in-built drives of our for-profit system.Â  Mackey has loudly declared unions akin to herpes and state regulation little more than â€œcrony capitalismâ€ â€” that all we need to solve things like the climate crisis are better, smarter, â€œconsciousâ€ capitalists. The crisis of Whole Foods belies this notion. Thereâ€™s no way to â€œfixâ€ corporationsâ€™ compulsion to produce ever more, ever more cheaply. Itâ€™s written into the DNA of global capitalism. Attractive as the conscious capitalism model may be, we simply canâ€™t rely on companies to deliver dignified workplaces, equitable models of food production or a better relationship between consumers and the planet.Â  All stakeholders are not equal in our global economy, and even the best-intentioned businesses run up against the implacable foes of profit and competition. Ultimately, the thorny problem of sustaining both decent livelihoods and a livable planet wonâ€™t be solved by buying better things. Itâ€™ll be solved through political struggle and demands that put people before profit. Home Mail Flickr Tumblr News Sports Finance Celebrity Answers Groups Mobile More Try Yahoo Finance on FirefoxÂ Â» Yahoo Search Search Sign in Finance Home Originals Events Personal Finance Technology Markets Industries My Screeners My Portfolio U.S. Markets open in 6 hrs 30 mins S&P 500 2,412.91 -2.91 (-0.12%) Dow 30 21,029.47 -50.81 (-0.24%) Nasdaq 6,203.19 -7.00 (-0.11%) Benzinga's Bulls And Bears For The Past Week: Ford, Kroger, Netflix And More Nelson Hem Benzinga May 30, 2017 Reblog Share Tweet Share The major indices eked out small gains this past week, ahead of the Memorial Day holiday in the United States and the unofficial beginning of the summer season. The first-quarter earnings reporting season is all but over, and the president was abroad for his first international trip as sitting head of state. Still, Benzinga has featured a look at many investor favorite stocks in recent days. Here is a look at just a few of them, as Americans travel, gather and remember those who made the ultimate sacrifice. Somewhere To Go "Analysts Cautiously Optimistic On Ford CEO Shakeup" by Shanthi Rexaline takes a look at the surprising management changes at Ford Motor Company (NYSE: F) announced last week. Is it a step in the right direction, and how effective will the new chief executive be? Are there spin-offs in the offing? In "Tesla's Safety Record Called Into Question, And The Market Couldn't Care Less," Shanthi Rexaline examines the effect that a recent report about safety issues at its flagship plant in California has had on Tesla Inc (NASDAQ: TSLA) shares. The stock has pulled back from an all-time high earlier this month. Something To Eat Ezra Schwarzbaum's "Wal-Mart Puts Pressure On Grocers, But Kroger Could Resist" discusses why even though recent gains at Wal-Mart Stores Inc (NYSE: WMT) may mean there is less for its supermarket competitors, Kroger Co (NYSE: KR) may be better positioned than other peers to suffer. Also check out "Nobody Told Costco About The Retail Slump." Years of interaction with Shake Shack Inc (NYSE: SHAK) have convinced one key analyst that it is a company that is "standing for something good," according to "Analyst Says Long-Term Investors In Shake Shack Should Continue Buying Shares" by Merrick Weingarten. Will profits really increase "at a double-digit pace"? Something To Watch In Elizabeth Balboa's "Which Media Firms Are Benefiting Most From President Trump?" see who the winners and losers are in the often combative relationship between the media and the current administration: from CBS Corporation (NYSE: CBS) to New York Times Co (NYSE: NYT) and from Fox News to Saturday Night Live. "Notable Netflix Analyst Says Stock Could See Another 67% Gain" by Jayson Derrick examines the question of whether Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ: NFLX) stock has peeked after a 75 percent gain in the past year. See why one analyst believes that the shares still have plenty of room to run. The Associated Press Sheriffâ€™s deputy shoots, kills man in Kansas City suburb RAYTOWN, Mo. â€” A Jackson County sheriffâ€™s deputy shot and killed a suspected shoplifter at a Wal-Mart in a Kansas City suburb. Sgt. John Payne says the shooting happened Sunday night in Raytown. He says the deputy, who was off-duty, was working security at Wal-Mart when she tried to help other employees stop the shoplifter. Payne says the suspect wrestled a stun gun away from the deputy and was able to stun the deputy. The deputy, whose name hasnâ€™t been released, drew her gun and shot him. See Also The man, 31-year-old Donald Sneed, of Kansas City, died later at a hospital. Payne said the deputy was treated and released at a hospital. News Sports Entertainment Life Obituaries E-Edition Cars Jobs Homes Classifieds log in Site Site Archive Sheriff's deputy shoots, kills man at Wal-Mart Monday MayÂ 29,Â 2017Â atÂ 8:54Â PM MayÂ 29,Â 2017Â atÂ 8:54Â PM By The Examiner staff A Jackson County Sheriff's deputy shot and killed a suspected shoplifter at a Wal-Mart in Raytown. The suspect was identified as Donald Sneed, 31 years old, of the Kansas City area. Sneed had active felony warrants for robbery and tampering with a motor vehicle. Sgt. John Payne says the shooting happened about 9:30 p.m., Sunday. He says the off-duty deputy was working security at the Wal-Mart at 10300 E. Missouri 350 when she recognized a wanted man. She notified the store's loss prevention department, which then watched as the suspect shoplifted some merchandise. Two store employees contacted the man as he left the store, and a struggle began. Payne says that when the deputy began helping with apprehending the man, he started fighting with her. She stunned him with her Taser, but it apparently had no effect on him as he continued resisting. The deputy then applied the stun gun directly to his body but it still had no effect. As they struggled, the suspect got control of the Taser and stunned the deputy in the neck. At that point, she shot the suspect, fearing for her life and others' lives, Payne says. Payne says the suspect was taken to a hospital, where he later died. The deputy was treated for injuries and released. Cummins, 50, has been charged with knowingly transporting a minor across state lines with the intent to engage in sexual activity and one charge of obstruction of justice. He faces from 10 years to a lifetime sentence in prison.Â Â Â  Cummins was arrested on April 21, five weeks after going on the run from Columbus, Tennessee, with 15-year-old Elizabeth Thomas, a student he had been grooming for years.Â  The pair sparked a nationwide manhunt and dyed their hair to evade capture.Â  Thirty-eight days after their disappearance, they were found hiding out in a rural cabin near Cecilville in northern California where a groundskeeper tipped off police. Cummins remains in custody in Tennessee. Cummins and Elizabeth were seen on surveillance footage in a Walmart days after they vanished. It's primetime at Amazon.com ... shares hit $1,000 - WAFB 9 News Baton Rouge, Louisiana News, Weather, Sports Member Center: Create Account| Log In Manage Account| Log Out SITE SEARCHWEB SEARCH BY HOME TRAFFIC MAPS/CAMERAS Hourly Forecast Information Top Trump aide exiting: First shoe to drop in wider shuffle? WAFB wins Murrow Award for Investigative Reporting VIDEO Louisiana Weekend Lagniappe Contests Slideshows Take A Road Trip Best of the Class: 2017 Double Day Stirrin It Up Recipes Recipe Calendars About Programming The WAFB 9News Mobile Apps 9News Internships Contact WAFB Anchors and Reporters Closed Captioning WAFB FCC Public File WBXH FCC Public File WAFB EEO File Advertise on the WAFB Network WAFB Jobs Grow Your Business It's primetime at Amazon.com ... shares hit $1,000 2017-05-31T06:13:15Z2017-05-31T06:13:15Z By JOSEPH PISANI AP Business Writer NEW YORK (AP) - Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. _____ Contact Joseph Pisani at http://twitter.com/josephpisani Copyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. All Rights Reserved Newspaper web site content management software and services 2017-05-31 / Local News Tweet Print Senior News The Clarence Senior Center is located at 4600 Thompson Road. Contact the center at 633-5138 to sign up for activities. When registering for free activities and programs, you can call the office or email your name, phone number and desired event(s) to signup@clarenceseniorcenter.org. Additional information is available at clarenceseniorcenter.org. Transportation The center has a 14-passenger bus available to provide transportation to members between their homes and the center. The bus, which is owned by the Town of Clarence, also takes members shopping to Tops, Wegmans, Target, Wal-Mart, Dashâ€™s and Eastern Hills Mall on a rotating basis Call the office at 633-5138 for more information or to make arrangements for pickup. Every week Monday: So-sew, 9:30 a.m.; woodworking, 9:30 a.m.; tap dancing, 10:15 a.m.; jazz dancing, 11:30 a.m.; billiards, noon; poker, 1 p.m.; euchre, 1 p.m. Tuesday: Menâ€™s bridge, 9 a.m.; womenâ€™s bridge, 9:15 a.m.; Scrabble, 10 a.m.; Eat, Live, Be Wellness Group, 10 a.m.; blood pressure screening, 10 a.m. to noon; resistance exercise, 11:30 a.m.; billiards, noon; intermediate bridge, 1 p.m. Wednesday: Euchre, 9 a.m.; beginner line dance, 9 a.m.; So-sew, 9:30 a.m.; ceramics, 9:30 a.m.; woodworking, 9:30 a.m.; line dance, 9:30 a.m.; computer support, 10 a.m. to noon; arthritis exercise, 11:15 a.m.; billiards, noon; bridge, 12:30 p.m.; watercolor painting, 1 p.m.; canasta, 1 p.m. Wednesday Evening: Billiards, 6:30 p.m.; pinochle, 6:30 p.m.; woodworking, 6:30 p.m. Thursday: Zumba, 9 a.m.; beginner bridge, 10 a.m.; tai chi, 11 a.m.; billiards, noon; duplicate bridge, 12:30 p.m.; poker, 1 p.m.; bingo, 1:15 p.m; shuffleboard, 1:15 p.m. Friday: Intermediate bridge, 9 a.m.; Stretch & Tone, 9 a.m.; Rummikub, 9:30 a.m.; Senior Outreach, 9:30 to 11 a.m.; computer support, 10 to 11:30 a.m.; resistance exercise, 11:30 a.m.; billiards, noon; pinochle, 1 p.m.; poker, 1 p.m.; dominoes, 1 p.m. Lunch at the Center Lunch is served daily at 12:30 p.m. for a suggested donation of $3 for those 60 years and older. Lunch is $5 for guests younger than 60. Menus featuring daily selections are available at the center. Calendar of Events University Express: â€˜Common Orthopedic Conditions of the Hand & Shoulderâ€™ 1:30 p.m. Wednesday, May 31 â€” Sprains, strains, tears, dislocations, arthritis, previous injuries and other debilitating joint conditions can interfere with every aspect of your life. Learn about the most common conditions for the hand and shoulder, how to avoid them, and how to treat them. The instructor will be Dr. Kory Reed, surgeon, Excelsior Orthopedics. Sign up in the office. Evening Bingo Bash 6:30 p.m. Wednesday, May 31â€” Bring a guest (21 and older) who has not played bingo at the center in the previous three months and you will receive a free card. Calling begins at 7 p.m. Refreshments will be served and prizes will be awarded. For bus service, inquire in the office. Sign up in the office. Travel News Cleveland Irish Cultural Festival Saturday, July 22, to Sunday, July 23 â€” A single ticket for this trip will cost $229, while a double ticket will cost $179. Each ticket buys admission to the two-day festival, a one-night accommodation and one breakfast at a hotel. The festival will feature two outdoor and seven indoor stages, 24 performers, pipe bands and entertainers, award-winning Irish plays each day, and more than 50 Irish vendors offering authentic Irish goods, foods and crafts. Note that this is not an escorted trip. Each passenger is responsible to follow his or her own itinerary. Make checks payable to Maxima Tours Ltd. (WLFI) â€” A Lafayette woman is accused of abandoning a 2-year-old at Wal-Mart. The incident happened Friday night at the store on Commerce Drive in Lafayette. Prosecutors said the loss prevention officer approached two women about shoplifting. The women took off but left behind a child in a stroller. Police said officers discovered a bag of spice inside a pocket on the stroller. They were also able to locate a receipt with the name of the childâ€™s father on it. Julie Wright, 35, was later identified as one of the women. Authorities said she was babysitting the child at the time. Charges against Wright are on a 72-hour hold. Prosecutors have until Friday afternoon to charge Wright or she will be released from the Tippecanoe County Jail, where sheâ€™s currently being held. Amazon opened the retail store Thursday. Amazon, the e-commerce giant that changed how people shop for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday, May 30: Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer) Mary Altaffer Share Tweet Share Email Comments NEW YORK â€” Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazonâ€™s market value at about $478 billion, double that of the worldâ€™s biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazonâ€™s first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, itâ€™s now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. Itâ€™s 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of Americaâ€™s most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macyâ€™s, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. online retailer's market value at double that of the world's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart. Associated Press Share Comment Read Article NEW YORK â€” Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazonâ€™s market value at about $478 billion, double that of the worldâ€™s biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazonâ€™s first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. GoSearch Replay: NewsFix CW39 TV Schedule Watch CW Shows Search Contact Us CW39 NewsFix Menu NewsFix Local Nation/World Features Community Entertainment Events EyeOpener Traffic Contests Weather 74Â° 74Â° Low 72Â° High 88Â° Wed 73Â° 88Â° Thu 73Â° 86Â° Fri 74Â° 86Â° See complete forecast Severe weather alert Amazon stock topsÂ $1,000 Posted 4:46 PM, May 30, 2017, by CNN Wire, Updated at 04:47PM, May 30, 2017 Facebook Twitter Pinterest Reddit LinkedIn Email Please enable Javascript to watch this video NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- Amazon the amazing! Shares of the online retail giant hit a new record high above $1,000 Tuesday. It's an impressive feat. Only one other stock in the S&P 500 -- Priceline -- has a stock price in the quadruple digits. Google parent Alphabet is also rapidly approaching this rarefied air. Its stock was trading at about $993. Amazon stock, which hit a new high of $1,001.20 before pulling back a bit, is now up nearly 35% this year. The company's market value is a staggering $478 billion, twice that of Walmart and trailing only Apple, Alphabet and Microsoft. And Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos is worth about $85 billion, according to Forbes and Bloomberg. That makes him richer than Warren Buffett and in a virtual tie with Spanish retail mogul Amancio Ortega in a tie for second richest person on the planet. Both Bezos and Ortega trail Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates by about $3 billion. Amazon's stock has soared thanks to strong results from its core retail business. It's even been opening physical stores, including a new one in Manhattan last week. The company also has a booming cloud computing business and has started to make bigger moves into media and advertising as well. As for Alphabet, its stock is up more than 25% this year. That's largely due to the continued dominance of its search engine -- and the ad dollars that come with that. But YouTube and Android are also generating more sales and profits for the company. Alphabet also has several so-called "other bets" -- companies like driverless car tech firm Waymo, Fiber and connected device maker Nest -- that are also starting to kick in more revenue. But how significant is it really that Amazon's stock is now above $1,000? It's really just a psychological milestone. Most professional investors don't look at just the stock price. They compare the price to the company's projected earnings. And on that basis, Amazon is pretty expensive. It's trading at about 90 times earnings estimates for next year, much higher than the overall market as well as other tech titans like Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and Facebook. The main reason that Amazon's share price has gotten to this level is that the company has not done a stock split since 1999. When a company splits its stock, it issues more shares to existing investors. That lowers the price of each share but doesn't change the value of that person's investment -- or the entire company. For example, if you owned 100 shares of a stock trading at $100 and the company decided to split its stock 2 for 1, you'd wind up with 200 shares at a price of $50 each. But investors (and financial reporters) love to focus on big round numbers. They are a lot easier to comprehend. Still, Amazon's and Alphabet's stock prices are important for another reason. If either company ever hope to be added to the illustrious Dow Jones Industrial Average, they will need to split their stock first. That's because the Dow is a price-weighted average and not a market cap-weighted index like the S&P 500. Adding a stock with a price north of $1,000 would give that company an outsized influence on the Dow's daily moves. Investment bank Goldman Sachs has the highest stock price in the Dow right now. But it's only about $220. Thirteen other Dow stocks have a price above $100, including Apple -- which trades at about $154. But Apple wasn't added to the Dow until 2015, a few months after the company did a 7 for 1 stock split that lowered its price from near $650 to about $92. Kim Christina Davidson, 46, of the 1600 block of Azure Lane was found shortly after 11 a.m. behind the Walmart at 4375 Parkway Village Circle, off Peters Creek Parkway, police said Monday. Officers received a report of a death at that scene and found Davidson beside a fence on the southern border of the store's property, police said. There were no signs of foul play. Davidson was taken to the Forsyth County Medical Examiner's Office at Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center for an autopsy, police said. Davidson's relatives have been notified of her death. Anyone with information about Davidson's death can call Crime Stoppers at (336) 727-2800. jhinton@wsjournal.com 336-727-7299 @jhintonWSJ Tags Kim Christina Davidson Criminal Law Crime Anatomy Police Foul Play Relative Stopper Medical Examiner John Hinton Follow John Hinton Close Get email notifications on John Hinton daily! Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR, and Seaboard combined. Itâ€™s 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of Americaâ€™s most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies, and US infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macyâ€™s, Borders bookstores, and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. Basics | Food and Dining Banking/Financial Services | Administration | Architect/Interior Design | Construction/Civil Engineer | Medical/Healthcare | Marketing Â  HOME > Business > Markets Amazon joins $1,000 club AP/New York Filed on May 30, 2017 Share More > Vote Only four other US-listed companies have shares that trade above $1,000 (AP) That price puts Amazon's market value at about $478 billion Amazon, the e-commerce giant that has changed how much of the world shops for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone. Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. That price puts Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of rival Wal-Mart and more than 15 times the size of Target. And its four-digit stock price places it in rare company: Only four other US-listed companies have shares that trade above $1,000. Amazon.com Inc. has come a long way since its start in 1995, when it mostly sold books. The Seattle firm now sells just about anything, from groceries to small appliances, and has been blamed for taking business away from department stores, supermarkets and clothing retailers. - AP Share More > Vote MORE FROM Business Markets Amazon joins $1,000 club That price puts Amazon's market value at about $478 billion READ MORE Technology Annual cybercrime costs set to hit $6T by 2021 With the annual global cybercrime costs set to escalate to an... Fast Talk podcast, ep. 6: Like it or not, you should be lifting Team SmartStopâ€™s winter training tips Before you get back in the saddle, make the gym your friend Eight keys to off-season success Watch/Listen/Read The VeloNews Show Podcasts Free email newsletter SUBSCRIBE Search VeloNews.com Search Search VeloNews Twitter VeloNews Facebook VeloNews Instagram VeloNews YouTube Home Â» Bikes and Tech Â» Technical FAQ Â» Technical FAQ: Quick links and more pedal thread questions Technical FAQ: Quick links and more pedal thread questions By Lennard Zinn Published May. 30, 2017 Photo: Tim De Waele | TDWsport.com (File). Dear Lennard, Yesterday on a ride, a buddy broke a chain link. I had a KMC 10-speed quick link and a tool, we both ride 10 speed Shimano, so the problem was quickly solved. However, we got to wondering about compatibility between drivetrains (9-, 10- and 11-speed, and Shimano/Campy). In a pinch, can you use a 10-speed quick link on an 11-speed (or 9-speed) chain? And do the links work for both Campy and Shimano? â€” John More Technical FAQ Technical FAQ: More on pedal thread direction Technical FAQ: Pedal threads and frame geometry Technical FAQ: Using Di2 Synchro Shift Technical FAQ: Hydraulic brakes, Van Avermaetâ€™s fork More Technical FAQ Technical FAQ: More on pedal thread direction Lennard Zinn tackles several follow-up questions and comments regarding his recent column on pedal thread direction. Dear John, You can use a 10-speed master link on an 11-speed chain, because the chain is narrower than the master link. But you cannot use a 10-speed master link on a 9-speed chain, because the chainâ€™s inner links will be wider than the inner width of the master link. You might get lucky mating one brand of 10-speed master link that happens to be a bit wider than most with another brand of 9-speed chain that happens to be a bit narrower than most. But in general, I would not expect it to work. Yes, the links work for both Campy and Shimano chains. I raced cyclocross for many years on 10-speed Campy and Shimano chains with Wippermann 10-speed master links holding them together. Same goes for my travel bike, on which I would remove the chain every time I put it in the bike case in order to not have everything end up in a tangle. I did discover, by breaking a master link once, that it is not a good idea to keep using the same master link when you replace your worn-out chain. I hadnâ€™t kept track, but Iâ€™m guessing I had replaced that chain at least three times and kept using the same master link over and over. It doesnâ€™t seem like a smart move now, but it sure was easy; hindsight is always 20/20. If you use a master link to hold your chain together, replace it when you replace the chain. â€• Lennard More on pedal thread direction Dear Lennard, I understand the mechanics behind the way pedals are threaded, but I can tell you also that Iâ€™ve personally helped two riders, with perfectly good pedals, re-attach them after they came off on steep climbs. Regardless of the intent behind the pedal threading, it seems even a good pedal can generate enough friction to slowly but surely unthread, if itâ€™s only hand tightened to start. â€” Steve Dear Steve, I also have a buddy who came across a guy on a local trail on a brand new mountain bike from Walmart whose pedal had just fallen off. â€• Lennard Dear Lennard, I enjoyed your ideas about pedal thread direction but I must disagree with part of your theory. It may be correct that if a bearing seized, and if the pedal werenâ€™t tightened very well on its threads, the pedal would just unscrew rather than breaking the leg of the rider or causing a crash. However, in my long experience working on and riding bicycles, the pedal threads tend to get so tight that they are difficult to loosen even with a wrench. I propose that in 99.99% of cases, if the bearing were to seize (which is a very rare situation nowadays), the pedal would not un-thread. The rider would either have to coast or, if he happened to be on a fixie, would still be likely to crash. Pedals are so infrequently removed, and then they get tightened by the â€œprecessionâ€ you mentioned, they are generally so tight that they could not be unscrewed by the riderâ€™s pedaling action even if they bearing seized. â€”Mike Dear Mike, I used to think that, too, until I saw my daughter pedal off two seized Crank Brothers pedals in cyclocross races. She doesnâ€™t live far from me, but once I helpÂ her set her bikes up for the season, she doesnâ€™t tend to ask me to work on them, and we certainly put the pedals on tightly, and those incidents happened in two different seasons. So Iâ€™m betting that those pedals were on there very tightly until the bearings started to seize. The constant power washing of â€™cross race bikes exposed the propensity of the needle bearings in that 2012ish-era Eggbeaters and Candys to seize up (current models have plastic Igus bushings, and Refresh Kits are available to replace the needle bearings with them). My theory is that the seizing of the pedal is a progressive thing, and as it happens over time, it is gradually unscrewing the pedals. Yes, a shoe attached to a cleat could not unscrew a tight pedal with a frozen bearing. But if the bearing freezes slowly over time, I am convinced that it can. Iâ€™ve seen it happen twice when I had firsthand knowledge of the circumstances. â€• Lennard More on Di2 Bluetooth and ANT+ connectivity Dear Lennard, So to summarize, the three options are: SM-EWW01: ANT+ only. Will connect to a Garmin that has ANT+. Will not connect to an iPhone, iPad, or Android device for programming. May be obsolete? EW-WU101: ANT+ only. Will connect to a Garmin that has ANT+. Will not connect to an iPhone, iPad, or Android device for programming. EW-WU111: ANT+ and Bluetooth. Will connect to a Garmin that has ANT+. Will also connect to an iPhone, iPad, or Android device for programming via E-Tube. Is that correct? â€”Ken Dear Ken, Youâ€™re correct on the first and third items, but not on the second. Both the EW-WU101 and EW-WU111 are Bluetooth and ANT compatible.Â They work with the e-Tube app on a phone or tablet as well as with a Garmin. They are interchangeable other than a geometry difference; the EW-WU111 is inline with a port on each end, and the EW-WU101 has both ports on the same end. You can put a D-Fly unit anywhere in the system. The EW-WU111, with ports on either end, facilitates hiding it inside the frame (although the signal will probably be weaker). The simplest method, if itâ€™s done as an afterthought, is to use the EW-WU101 on the lower seat stay.Â Just unplug the rear derailleur; you run the rear derailleur wire up from where it pops out of the end of the chain stay and plug it into one port on the EW-WU101. Then, run a short wire from the other port to the rear derailleur. The photo is of the EW-WU101 on my gravel road bike, mounted as I just described; I havenâ€™t used the EW-WU111. As long as youâ€™re not using the satellite (climbing) shifter, you can instead use the SC-M9051 or SC-MT800 Bluetooth/ANT+ digital display units for XTR Di2 and XT Di2, respectively, on a road bike. The digital display only has three ports, though. If youâ€™re using a climbing shifter, you need the 5-port Junction A, which is not a transceiver. â€• Lennard LATEST MOST READ GEAR RACE REPORTS Pro cycling fixture Sean Weide dies unexpectedly 4 hours ago NEWS Summerhill, UHC part ways following gun charge 8 hours ago NEWS Technical FAQ: Quick links and more pedal thread questions 11 hours ago TECHNICAL FAQ Giro Photo Essay: Fight for pink in fearsome final week 11 hours ago PHOTO ESSAY VIEW ALL NEWS Dumoulin apology doesnâ€™t deter Nibaliâ€™s attacks 4 days ago GIRO D'ITALIA Quintana believes late sickness cost him the Giro 3 days ago NEWS Garbage Takes: Giro in the toilet; Tejay is back! 5 days ago COMMENTARY Dumoulin: â€˜I made a rookie mistakeâ€™ 5 days ago GIRO D'ITALIA Technical FAQ: Quick links and more pedal thread questions 11 hours ago TECHNICAL FAQ Tech FAQ: More on pedal thread direction 1 week ago BIKES AND TECH Canyon sets new standard for women's bikes 2 weeks ago NEWS Week in Tech: Strava commutes, Steve McQueen helmets, new Zipps 2 weeks ago NEWS VIEW ALL GEAR Stage 21: Tom Dumoulin delivers in decisive TT 3 days ago GIRO D'ITALIA Stage 20: Quintana can't break Dumoulin; Pinot wins 4 days ago GIRO D'ITALIA Stage 19: Quintana seizes lead from Dumoulin 5 days ago GIRO D'ITALIA Stage 17: Rolland gives breakaway the slip 7 days ago GIRO D'ITALIA VIEW ALL RACE REPORTS Get VeloNews In Your Inbox Free! (Published Tuesday, May 30, 2017) The passenger involved in a fiery car crash on Memorial Day in Reading, Massachusetts, is sharing her story for the first time. Seventeen-year-old Allison McCaffrey and her aunt, Laura McCaffrey, were on their way to Wal-Mart, when Laura started to have a seizure behind the wheel. "I kind of just, all of the sudden, heard her scream," recalled McCaffrey. "Then the car just went forward." The teen had little time to react but knew she had to get the car to stop. Reading Crash Survivor Speaks Out The passenger involved in a fiery car crash on Memorial Day in Reading, Massachusetts, is sharing her story for the first time.(Published Tuesday, May 30, 2017) "I didn't really know what to do, so I grabbed onto the wheel," said McCaffrey. "[I] started turning the car on my own, so we didn't crash into any other cars." McCaffrey not only grabbed the wheel, but tried to get her aunt's foot off the gas pedal as she tried to dodge other cars on the road. "I was grabbing on to Laura's leg, trying to move it off the gas, and that's when I noticed the road was taking a curve," said McCaffrey. "And there was a pole in front of me." Mass. Cookout Hero Rescues Woman From Burning Car It ended with a crash into a utility pole. McCaffrey blacked out, but she came to and jumped out of the car. She realized her aunt was unconscious and the door was jammed. Flames were shooting from the vehicle. Series of Bombings Kill Nearly 40 People Across Baghdad "I was screaming out Laura's name," said McCaffrey. "I didnâ€™t know what to do." Suddenly, some people who heard the commotion showed up, including Brandon Finnen, who started to use a baseball bat to break the car windows. He and another man then dragged Laura to safety. Tiger Woods Says Prescribed Meds Led to DUI Arrest McCaffrey knows they were lucky, and she has a message for the people who helped. "I want to say thank you, because I don't know what would have happened if you guys weren't there," said McCaffrey. "Laura probably would have been dead ... there's not a lot of people like you out there these days." McCaffrey suffered a sprained ankle. Her aunt remains hospitalized with a broken ankle and will be undergoing surgery. Amazon, the e-commerce giant that changed how people shop for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday, May 30: Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. Mary Altaffer AP Photo National Business May 30, 2017 2:01 PM It's primetime at Amazon.com ... shares hit $1,000 By JOSEPH PISANI AP Business Writer LinkedIn Google+ Pinterest Reddit Print Order Reprint of this Story NEW YORK Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. In this Thursday, May 25, 2017, photo, gift cards are on display at the Amazon Books store in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, in New York. Amazon opened the retail store Thursday. Amazon, the e-commerce giant that changed how people shop for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday, May 30: Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. Amazon opened the retail store Thursday. Amazon, the e-commerce giant that changed how people shop for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday, May 30: Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. Mary Altaffer AP Photo This Thursday, May 25, 2017, photo, shows the Amazon Books store logo at the company's retail store in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, in New York. Amazon, the e-commerce giant that changed how people shop for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday, May 30: Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. shares hit $1,000 for the first time By Joseph Pisani 7:42 AM Wednesday May 31, 2017 SHARE: Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Not saved Email Print Amazon.com Business Services Mobile Business Retail Trade Retailing Shopping United States The internet goliath has hit a new milestone. Photo / 123RF Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionised the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone. Its stock surpassed the US$1,000 (NZ$1409) mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about US$478 billion (NZ$673b), double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A US$1,000 (NZ$1409) investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than US$500,000 (NZ$704,000) today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet, the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the US$1,000 level, with its Class A shares just US$2 short of US$1,000 Tuesday. Only four other US-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group, home builder NVR, pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 per cent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and US infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. Skip to main content Labs Blog Mobile About Us Help Login / Register Home Updates Countries Disasters Topics Organizations Jobs Training 30 May 2017 Monitoring and Evaluation Officer- 1 Vacancy based in Moroto (Open to Ugandan Nationals Only) Jobfrom Mercy Corps â€” Closing date: 02 Jun 2017 PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY: Mercy Corps has been operating in Uganda since 2006 and works to catalyze change makers within the Ugandan private sector, civil society and government to create economically dynamic, healthy and secure communities. Our works focus on building resilience and enabling economic growth, improving opportunities to attain better health and nutrition, and improving governance and conflict management. We implement programs in the northern districts of Pader, Kitgum, Agago, Lamwo, Kaabong, Abim, Kotido, Moroto, Napak, Nakapiripirit and Amudat with funding from USAID, USDA, Walmart Foundation, Nike Foundation, SDC, DFID as well as other private donations. BRACED Mercy Corps is a consortium led by Mercy Corps that includes TANGO Intl, Makerere University, University of Nairobi and Wajir South Development Association (WASDA). BRACED Mercy Corps is being implemented in northern Uganda (Karamoja) as well as northern Kenya (Wajir County). The BRACED Mercy Corps programme is designed around three integrated thematic focus areas - Natural Resource Management and Lands, Market Systems Development and Governance and Gender Mainstreaming. We are in search of an inquisitive individual to support project staff in conducting research and gathering and analysing quantitative and qualitative data to help communicate the programâ€™s impact to various audiences â€“ stakeholders, donors and internal Mercy Corps team members. GENERAL POSITION SUMMARY: The Monitoring and Evaluation Officer (M&E) will work closely with the Project Managers and Program Director to track, analyse and document learnings for the BRACED activities. The M&E Officer will help create tracking tools to ensure team members and community members are reaching their goals. S/he will work with teams to identify critical knowledge gaps and carry out targeted research on those areas, engaging external assistance, when necessary. ESSENTIAL JOB FUNCTIONS: Monitoring and Evaluation: Â· Develop tools to simplify data gathering and reporting and ensure teams gather and report necessary data Â· Support program staff in monitoring and evaluating the progress and impact of work including setting and measuring benchmarks along results chains; Â· Manage program data; including information that is collected by programs, this will include database support and design. Â· Development and maintain a central database to track all PMP-required project information, and provide to the program manager, on request Â· Prepare data analyses to be used in monthly program strategic reviews, annual reports, and other evaluations. Â· Quickly learn and administer the DPMELC system and TOLA as the monitoring and evaluation systems used by Mercy Corps Applied learning and Research: Â· Lead applied learning activities in the M&E field including conducting M&E trainings, evaluations, reviews etc. Â· Keenly analyze and share data and information for effective decision making Â· Coordinate program/project lessons learnt and develop key actions of improvement Â· Participate in conducting research activities on specific subjects critical to team success and recommend hiring of external support where necessary; Capacity building Â· Facilitate capacity building of staff on DMELC system and TOLA, stakeholders and beneficiaries on assessment, monitoring and evaluation Â· Carry out a one-to-one for project staff on how to use developed data collection tools Â· Assist program staff develop monitoring and evaluation tools Communication and Publication: Â· Contribute data, analysis and write-ups to regular organizational publications and reports; Â· Work closely with the Monitoring and Evaluation officer to develop publishable communication material about BRACED in Karamoja; Â· Other: Â· Conduct himself/herself both professionally and personally in such a manner as to bring credit to Mercy Corps and to not jeopardize its humanitarian mission; KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE: Â· The ideal candidate for the BRACED Learning and Information Office opportunity should possess a Bachelor's degree preferably in BSc (Economics), BSc (Statistics), B. Quantitative Economics, B. Population Studies or Development studies with a certificate level qualification in computer applications. Â· At least 3 years of related professional experience Â· Demonstrable quantitative skills, including familiarity with database management and analysis Â· Superior writing and analytical skills Â· Proven skills in networking, assessing information needs and developing appropriate tools Â· Excellent reporting, communication and representation skills Â· Knowledge of Ugandaâ€™s economy and business environment, particularly in the context of rural development and Karamoja. Â· Skilled in promoting organization learning and knowledge acquisition and sharing How to apply: Applications: Submit your application through email to ug-mcjobs@mercycorps.org addressed to the Senior HR and Legal Manager, Mercy Corps Uganda. Include a cover letter clearly stating your salary requirements, CV (with 3 referees), and copies of academic qualifications/certificates. Deadline for Submission: Close of business on Friday, 2nd June, 2017. Subject of email should include the position you are applying for. Only short-listed candidates will be contacted by Mercy Corps. Mercy Corps is an equal opportunity employer; qualified female candidates are strongly encouraged to apply. Job ID: #2051934 Country: Uganda Years of experience: 3-5 years Job type: Job How to apply Home Updates Countries Disasters Topics Organizations Jobs Training About Us Help ReliefWeb Informing humanitarians worldwide. Amazon shares rise above $1,000 for the first time Money Tuesday 30 May 2017 - 5:26pm File: Shares of Amazon breached $1,000 on Tuesday. When the online retailer was first listed 20 years ago they were $18 a share. Photo: AFP PHOTO / Emmanuel Dunand NEW YORK - Shares of Amazon surged above $1,000 for the first time on Tuesday, marking another milestone in the rise of the American online retail giant. At about 14.10 GMT, the company's shares were selling at $997.97, up 0.2 percent after earlier getting as high as $1,001.20. Amazon's market capitalisation stood at about $478-billion, more than twice that of Wal-Mart Stores. After going in public in May 1997 at $18 a share, Amazon has benefited from tectonic shifts in US technology and consumer shopping habits that are expected to continue to remake the retail industry. READ: Amazon expands global reach with Souq.com buy The company has evolved from its origins as an online bookseller into a broad-based retailer of apparel and household staples, from electronics to sausage casing. And with its "Prime" subscription service, it also has become a creative force in Hollywood and beyond. Amazon shares have appreciated especially rapidly over the last three years in anticipation that e-commerce will become a much bigger force in the retail sector. Online sales currently comprise about eight percent of the US retail market. Amazon alone accounts for about 43 percent of US online sales, according to consultancy Slice Intelligence. E-commerce is expected to grow between eight and 12 percent this year, according to the National Retail Federation, about three times as much as the rest of the industry, which has faced massive store and mall closures. Amazon, whose revenues grew to $35.7-billion in the first quarter, has impressed Wall Street by also laying out a plan to achieve greater profitability. It is in the process of investing $1.5-billion to establish its own delivery network and lessen its dependence on shipping giants FedEx and UPS. That will help contain delivery costs, which grew 30 percent to $1.9-billion in the first quarter. The surge above $1,000 a share also raises questions about whether Amazon intends to pursue a stock split. At Amazon's annual meeting a week ago, chief executive Jeff Bezos said the matter was under consideration. The company had three previous stock splits, in June 1998 and in January and August 1999. On Tuesday, May 30, the Nintendo Switch is not available online. The Switch bundles sold at online atÂ gamestop.comÂ sold out on Memorial Day.Â The video game retailer offeredÂ two new Nintendo Switch bundles priced for under $400.Â  Don't Miss:Â Find Rare Products in Stock Online with The Tracker The Nintendo Switch availability hit a low again also at retail locations. As reported earlier, the reason for the low supply is the upcoming E3 2017 video game conference and the release of Arms on June 16. Nintendo will want to have the Switch in stock for the video game show when the buzz hits a new high. The only way to get a Nintendo Switch online now is at reseller market places like Amazon. The Nintendo Switch reseller markups keep steady and range today betweenÂ $88 to $110Â for the Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy-Con andÂ $95 to $130Â for the Nintendo Switch with Neon Joy-Con onÂ amazon.com. The Nintendo Switch with Neon Joy-Con is more rare than the console with Gray controllers, resulting in considerable higher market value. Overall the Nintendo Switch market prices have staid flat. Read the reseller offers carefully and check the feedback. Some low priced offers have shipping dates in July. Walmart for the first time in the past two months has not sold the Nintendo Switch online in a bundleÂ on Friday at 5pm ET. The retailer finally reacts to the over selling problem. It will arrive on June 1. Our Nintendo Switch Giveaway will launch soon after we received the Switch in the office. This could mean that Walmart is able to offer limited Nintendo Switch inventory again on walmart.com this Friday at 5pm ET. Looking at the current shortage, the Japanese video game maker has a long road ahead of them to ship 101 million Nintendo Switch consoles.
