Nintendo is ramping up the production for the Nintendo Switch, but has not disclosed what the current production capacity per month is. The demand for the Nintendo Switch will spike during the Holiday Shopping season 2017. Nintendo will set aside a large part of the Switch production during the next months for November and December. This stock piling will keep the Nintendo Switch in short supply during the next 5 months. As Nintendo coordinated new Switch console shipment with the launch of Mario Kart 8, we expect the company to do the same for the next major Switch game launches. This means theÂ next big wave of new Switch consolesÂ comes in mid-June for the release of ARMS. The Nintendo Switch will likely be offered in special bundles in time for the Holidays. AÂ Mario Kart 8 Deluxe Switch bundleÂ has already surfaced in Russia. Because of the incredible demand for the Switch console, the monetary savings on these bundles will be limited. Usually bundles offer a way for consumers to get a free game. Nintendo can afford to just offer some savings, unless the demand is slowing down. Read theÂ latest Nintendo Switch news. Photo Credit: AP advertisement | advertise on newsday Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Most Popular LI firm owner seeks younger version of himself LI publishing plant employing 51 to shut down 22 LI Chipotle locations among 2,250 hacked IDA awards $50G for worker-owned businesses LI company considers financial â€˜alternativesâ€™ Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. advertisement | advertise on newsday Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. Get the Biz Briefing newsletter! The losses threaten a seven-day winning streak for major stock indexes. Advertisement Technology companies and consumer-focused companies continue to climb. Amazon.com is among them. It briefly surpassed $1,000 a share for the first time. Security software maker Symantec, chipmaker Nvidia and 3 percent and Micron Technology are also gaining. International airlines slumped as the government considered expanding a ban on laptops from the passenger cabins of flights to the United States. CONSUMER CONFIDENCE Consumer confidence slips in May but still at high levels WASHINGTON (AP) â€” U.S. consumers were slightly less confident in May for the second straight month, but they remain bullish overall. The Conference Board says its consumer confidence index fell to 117.9 from 120.3 in April. The index hit 124.9 in March, its highest mark in 16 years. The index that measures consumersâ€™ feelings about the current economic situation increased slightly, while the index measuring consumersâ€™ sentiment about the future was down slightly. Consumersâ€™ outlook for the job market was also mixed. Economists closely monitor the mood of consumers because their spending makes up about 70 percent of U.S. economic activity. CONSUMER SPENDING US consumer spending, incomes grew solidly in April WASHINGTON (AP) â€” Americans increased their spending in April at the fastest pace in four months, bolstered by a solid gain in incomes. The strong results underscored expectations that the economy is poised to rebound after a lackluster start to the year. The Commerce Department says consumer spending rose 0.4 percent in April after a 0.3 percent rise in March. It was the best showing since December. Incomes rose 0.4 percent. Consumer spending, which accounts for 70 percent of economic activity, grew at the slowest pace in seven years in the first quarter. That was a key reason the economy expanded by just 1.2 percent at the start of the year. Economists are hopeful growth will rebound to around 3 percent in the current April-June quarter. HOME PRICES US home prices rising 2 times faster than wages WASHINGTON (AP) â€” U.S. home prices climbed in March at the strongest rate in nearly three year as a dwindling supply of houses for sale is causing prices to significantly outpace income growth. The Standard & Poorâ€™s CoreLogic Case-Shiller 20-city home price index rose 5.9 percent over the past 12 months ended in March, the most since July 2014. Home values are increasing at more than double the pace of average hourly earnings, making it more difficult for many people to afford to buy a home. A steady job market has bulked up demand among many would-be buyers, but there are fewer properties on the market. Sales listings have plummeted 9 percent over the past year to 1.93 million, according to the National Association of Realtors. AMAZON-1K STOCK Amazonâ€™s stock tops $1,000 for the first time UNDATED (AP) â€” Amazon stock reached a milestone today, topping at $1,000 for the first time. That puts the e-commerce giantâ€™s market value at $478 billion, double that of rival Wal-Mart and more than 15 times the size of Target. And its four-digit stock price places it in rare company: Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares that trade above $1,000. Amazon.com Inc. has come a long way since its start in 1995, when it mostly sold books. The Seattle company now sells just about anything, from groceries to small appliances, and has been blamed for taking business away from department stores, supermarkets and clothing retailers. GENERAL MOTORS STOCK Proxy fight over GM stock heats up ahead of annual meeting DETROIT (AP) â€” Shares of General Motors are rising as a proxy fight escalates between the company and an activist shareholder who wants to split its shares into two classes. David Einhornâ€™s Greenlight Capital says itâ€™s sending a letter to shareholders emphasizing that the stock price has barely grown since GMâ€™s initial public offering at $33 seven years ago. GM pointed out last week that two independent, corporate evaluation firms, ISS and Glass Lewis, recommended against the proposal. Shares of GM rose 1 percent to $33.40 shortly after the opening bell. Greenlightâ€™s plan would create one dividend-paying stock and one â€œcapital allocationâ€ stock designed for growth. GM says the stock split is too risky. A vote will take place in one week at the annual shareholders meeting on June 6. WESSON OIL SOLD Conagra Brands sells Wesson brand for $285M to Smucker OMAHA, Neb. (AP) â€” Conagra Brands is selling Wesson oil for $285 million to the J.M. Smucker Company as it continues to reshape the company to focus on its strongest consumer brands. Conagra CEO Sean Connolly says the Wesson sale is part of the reorganization that he has overseen since taking over in 2015. Conagra moved its headquarters to Chicago from Omaha, Nebraska, and unloaded its store brand and frozen potato businesses. Smucker says Wesson is expected to add $230 million in sales and roughly $30 million in pretax earnings. CEO Mark Smucker says Wesson will complement its Crisco brand nicely. Conagra will initially continue producing Wesson after the sale until the work moves to Smuckerâ€™s existing oil manufacturing plant in Cincinnati, Ohio. CHINA-TRUMP TRADEMARKS Senate Democrats ask Trump for answers on China trademarks SHANGHAI (AP) â€” Senate Democrats have sent a letter to U.S. President Donald Trump requesting information about a raft of trademark approvals from China this year that they say may violate the U.S. Constitutionâ€™s ban on gifts from foreign governments. The eight senators say in the letter today that Chinaâ€™s rapid approval of the trademarks after years of court battles raised questions about whether they would prevent Trump from standing up to China on behalf of American workers and their businesses. China has granted or provisionally granted 40 trademarks to the president and a related company, DTTM Operations LLC, since his inauguration. If there are no objections, provisional approvals are formally registered after 90 days. China has also rejected or partially rejected nine Trump trademarks since the inauguration. BRITAIN-BRITISH AIRWAYS Shares in British Airwaysâ€™ parent company tumble LONDON (AP) â€” Shares in British Airwaysâ€™ parent company tumbled today after a catastrophic IT failure stranded thousands of passengers during a long holiday weekend. Shares in the International Airlines Group dropped about 3 percent in the first day of trading after a weekend that saw hundreds of flights canceled after a power surge led to an IT meltdown. Although the airline is running a full schedule of flights today, it acknowledges that passengers are still facing baggage delays. The company has apologized, but shareholders have not been forgiving. Kathleen Brooks, the research director at City Index, says investors are concerned the troubles suggested that cost-cutting at IAG have gone too far. THREE MILE ISLAND Owner says Three Mile Island plant to shut down in 2019 HARRISBURG, Pa. (AP) â€” The owner of Three Mile Island, site of the United Statesâ€™ worst commercial nuclear power accident, says it will shut down the plant in 2019 without a financial rescue from Pennsylvania. Exelon Corp. says Mondayâ€™s announcement comes after five years of losses on the power plant and its recent failure in an auction to sell Three Mile Islandâ€™s power into the regional grid. The Chicago-based energy company wants Pennsylvania to give nuclear power megawatts the kind of preferential treatment and premium payments that are given to renewable energies, such as wind and solar. Nuclear power plants have been hammered by the natural gas boom that has slashed electricity prices in competitive markets. Equipment failure and operator errors at Three Mile Island in 1979 led to partial core meltdown of a reactor. The plantâ€™s other reactor is still in use. COAL POWER PLANTS CLOSING PSEG closing its 2 final New Jersey coal-fired power plants HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J. (AP) â€” The largest energy provider in New Jersey is set to close its final coal-fired power plants. Public Service Enterprise Group will close the Mercer and Hudson generation stations on Thursday as inexpensive natural gas has made it no longer profitable to run the coal plants. Ralph Izzo, chief executive of PSEG Power, tells the Philadelphia Inquirer that the company made a bad bet on high gas prices. The company took a $555 million loss on the plant closures last year and expects to write off up to $960 million this year. MIAMI MEGAMALL Retail-tainment: Donâ€™t call biggest US mall in Miami a mall MIAMI (AP) â€” Call it retail-tainment. Just donâ€™t call American Dream Miami a mall. Developers are proposing a massive 6 million-square-foot (557,000 square-meter) project on the edge of the Everglades in bustling South Florida that would dwarf any other shopping mecca in North America, including Minnesotaâ€™s Mall of America. Miami-Dade County officials could approve it this fall, despite criticism that it will worsen the regionâ€™s already choking traffic problem and produce mostly low-paying jobs. And malls have been in decline as shoppers flock to the internet. Developer Triple Five Worldwide Group of Edmonton, Canada, says this will be different, combining retail space with an indoor ski slope, a water park, a submarine ride attraction, a skating rink, 2,000 hotel rooms, theaters, a performing arts center, and places to eat and drink. FEARLESS GIRL-DOG Urinating dog statue briefly placed near â€˜Fearless Girlâ€™ art NEW YORK (AP) â€” A New York City artist says he was expressing himself by placing the statue of a dog relieving itself near Wall Streetâ€™s â€œFearless Girlâ€ sculpture. Artist Alex Gardega tells The New York Post that he thinks â€œFearless Girlâ€ is a disrespectful publicity stunt and â€œhas nothing to do with feminism.â€ He says the urinating dog id a form of counter protest. A financial firm installed â€œFearless Girlâ€ in March as a statement about the lack of women on the boards of big U.S. corporations. It faces the famous â€œCharging Bullâ€ statue. It's primetime at Amazon.com ... shares hit $1,000 - WBRC FOX6 News - Birmingham, AL Member Center: Create Account| Log In Manage Account| Log Out SITE SEARCHWEB SEARCH BY Home Watch LIVE Newscasts & Replays Seen on WBRC FOX6 News Live Video & Events Download WBRC apps Seen on TV Traffic Tracker Editorials Recipes Delays and Closings News Download the WBRC News app Alabama Headlines National Tuscaloosa News Local Sports News Traffic Tracker Good Day Recipes Recalls Weather Download the WBRC Weather app Delays and Closings Weather Blog FutureCast SkyVision Cameras Zip Code Forecast Traffic Tracker Mickey's Weather Kids How to program a NOAA weather radio First Alert Weather Tour WBRC First Alert Severe Weather Policy WBRC First Alert Storm Tracker, powered by Town & Country Ford iHeartMedia Radio Partners Sports Alabama Auburn UAB Samford JSU Download the Sideline Plus app WBRC FOX6 Sideline Tide and Tigers Today Karle's Korner Alabama Sports Headlines Video Live Video Right This Minute Video Special Features Videos Sports Videos Editorials Videos Good Day Videos Weather Videos Share Photos and Videos Video Requests Good Day Traffic Tracker Contest Entry Page Recipes Business Break Mickey's Weather Kids Pet Pics Magic City Weekend Features Fugitive Finder Road Warrior Heart Gallery Alabama #WBRCandMe Pet Pics Weddings Home and Garden Food Health Money Auto Home/Family Tech TV Watch LIVE Newscasts & Replays Live Video & Events FOX Broadcasting Company Bounce TV Grit TV Absolutely Alabama Right This Minute About Us Meet the Team WBRC FOX6 News Job Opportunities WBRC FOX6 News Internship Program 2016 EEOC Public File Report It's primetime at Amazon.com ... shares hit $1,000 2017-05-31T06:13:15Z2017-05-31T06:13:15Z By JOSEPH PISANI AP Business Writer NEW YORK (AP) - Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. _____ Contact Joseph Pisani at http://twitter.com/josephpisani Copyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Taiwo's baby story is extremely rare. In 2015, only 24 of the 4 million live births in the US were quintuplets, sextuplets or higher. 1:37 This overbred French bulldog has no eyes Milly is a dog with no eyes but a lot of heart. You may unsubscribe at any time. Are you a print subscriber? Activate your account. Missing the Point: $100 Billion in Loyalty Points Are Unclaimed By Kate Kaye. Published on May 26, 2017. Credit: ayo888/iStock As more consumers participate in brand loyalty programs, more of those loyalty points are going unclaimed -- to the tune of $100 billion, according to marketing firm Bond Brand Loyalty. The problem for marketers is that if consumers aren't taking advantage of the points they're accumulating by cashing them in, they may not have a positive view of the program. (Worse, unclaimed rewards create a financial liability for brands.) There are number of reasons why such bounty is left sitting in wallets. It is in part a question of educating consumers: Some brand loyalty marketers are failing to communicate reminders about redeemable points to program members. "Some people don't redeem because they are disengaged with the program, even to the extent that they don't know their current points balance or what redemption options are available to them," said Sean Claessen, executive VP of strategy and innovation at Bond Brant Loyalty. Source: Bond Brand Loyalty's 2017 Loyalty Report A recent study by Accenture found that 77% of consumers participate in some kind of a retail loyalty program, 46% have joined a hotel program, and 40% are part of an airline programâ€“up from 72%, 36%, and 31% over the last year, respectively. Brand loyalty programs that rate highest when it comes to ease of points tracking and account activity were Papa John's Papa Rewards, Domino's Pizza Pizza Profile, MyMK from Mary Kay Cosmetics, Walmart Savings Catcher and H-E-B Points Club Rewards, from the Texas-based grocery chain. However, not all loyalty customers are in it just for the immediate reward of cheaper gas or cash back on purchases. According to Claessen, some loyalty members have a method to what seems like the madness of not redeeming. Some points hoarders, for instance, prefer to maintain a minimum balance of grocery loyalty points just in case they forget their wallet while picking up last-minute ingredients for dinner. And others are aspirational -- building up points to score flights or hotel reservations for that once-in-a-lifetime vacation. In other words, Claessen said, unredeemed points aren't always a signal that marketers are doing something wrong. However, he added, there probably is room for improvement in many cases. "To improve member engagement and drive redemption behavior, you should encourage goal setting, foster better awareness of accumulation status and communicate progress on a regular basis." To arrive at its $100 billion tally, the company surveyed more than 28,000 consumers in the US and Canada in relation to more than 400 different loyalty programs from credit card and airline loyalty to casual dining and retail. It calculated the value of the average balance of unredeemed points in each loyalty sector evaluated, factoring in the number of consumers in those programs and their activity rates. For consumers, the promise of loyalty programs are the rewards. So, it stands to reason that if they aren't redeeming points, they may not feel as though that promise is fulfilled. It turns out, according to the Bond report, redeemers are twice as likely to be highly satisfied with their programs than non-redeemers, and only a quarter of loyalty members are very satisfied with the level of effort required to earn a reward or benefit. Plus, a lot of people have no idea what benefits they qualify for because they don't know their points levels. According to the report, 57% of members don't know their points balance, and 38% are unaware of their points value. Amazon, the e-commerce giant that changed how people shop for books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday, May 30: Its stock topped $1,000 for the first time. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer) NEW YORK (AP) â€” Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. _____ Contact Joseph Pisani at http://twitter.com/josephpisani Get news headlines sent daily to your inbox Sign Up! MTV By Mark Shrayber May 30, 2017 I have seen paradise and this is what it looks like: Three teen moms, one Puerto Rican vacation, and an unlimited supply of tears. In paradise, there are paddle boats and kayaks. Amber frowns on the beach instead of indoors. Matt is downed over and over by waves that know exactly what he is. Catelynn swims in a pool on her balcony, whooping over and over and for no reason. And Maci convinces her castmate that the only appropriate place to hide birthday decorations are high between oneâ€™s legs and inside a well-filled bra. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below In paradise, the men of Teen Mom OG enjoy cocktails that are meant to simulate â€œcoochie cream.â€ In paradise, Catelynn sees a rooster and does not immediately demand one for her own. In paradise, there is no Farrah Abraham, but she is constantly being talked about, as if she may jump from behind any corner in FroCo sunglasses and â€œpublic speakâ€ about her business ventures, which she dove into after having a child and realizing that no one could fill the frozen yogurt and â€œreasonably priced furniture sold by bored teens who want to be on TVâ€ niche as well as she, a mom, could. Close your eyes and picture paradise with me, friend. Do you see an endless high-speed montage of store and restaurant names which provided promotional consideration for Catelynnâ€™s tropical vacation? Can you hear the happy laughter of three women who donâ€™t know that Puerto Rico isnâ€™t Mexico or Spain? Open your eyes: youâ€™re there. Catelynn, Maci, and Amber Your grandparents may have listened to songs that extolled the pleasures of a heaven meant for two, but if thereâ€™s one thing we all learned this week, itâ€™s that paradise isnâ€™t paradise unless it involves five people and a sentient pile of hot garbage talking shit about a seventh person who wasnâ€™t invited. And because all three stars of this show â€” Farrah isnâ€™t really a person of import, the other women agreed, while having another conversation about her â€” converged upon one resort for a week of more tears than laughter, Iâ€™m lumping all of them into one glorious section, a â€œsmorgashorgasbjrhfbfhhifbhfurdâ€ (to quote Catelynn) of earthly delights. It begins with invitations: Catelynn wants to do something special for her birthday so she asks Amber and Maci (and their partners, Phil Robertson and a bin of trash left outside too long on a hot day) to hop a plane and get their butts to Puerto Rico for some fun in the sun (â€œovercast but very warmâ€ just doesnâ€™t have the same ring to it.) Both enthusiastically agree, although Matt and Amber are still fighting about everything and Maciâ€™s worried about Ryan (on drugs) and Bentley (needs a ride to soccer practice). Advertisement - Continue Reading Below In Puerto Rico, Catelynn tells Tyler that sheâ€™s really excited to eat some â€œreally good Spanish foodâ€ and then waxes poetic about how she should have been born Spanish instead of a white girl in Michigan. Amber, who was not destined to be born Spanish like Catelynn, suggests that they have sandwiches for lunch. But like really good sandwiches. The ladies leave the hotel to buy food and find themselves in a supermarket where they decide that they want to surprise Catelynn with whatever decorations are on hand in aisle nine. Amber and Maci discuss how to hide the decorations so that they may remain a surprise and try â€œbetween Amberâ€™s legsâ€ and â€œall up in Amberâ€™s braâ€ before settling on â€œletâ€™s get Catelynn outside while the guys check out so she canâ€™t see what weâ€™re getting.â€ Not that it matters, though. The guys are pushing so many pallets of alcohol to the counter that no one would ever notice a â€œHappy Birthdayâ€ banner and a couple of balloons among the many bottles of Bud Light and tequila theyâ€™re about to get turnt on. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below But then it gets serious: Because no trip would be complete without tears and Amber once again storming off for seemingly no reason (to be explained in great detail to producers later), the ladies begin a series of heart-to-hearts about what itâ€™s like to be a Teen Mom, how difficult marriage is, and how much theyâ€™ve all learned. MTV First up in the hot seat is Catelynn, who has to leave the group during a discussion of postpartum depression. Maci says that she suffered from it after giving birth to Jayde, which leads to a conversation about whether moms suffer postpartum with every kid, which eventually leads to a conversation about Carlie (the daughter Catelynn and Tyler gave up for adoption). Catelynn wanders off to be by herself for a while because itâ€™s just too intense to talk about her first child on vacation and Tyler tells the others that Catelynn feels really guilty about giving her first child up for adoption and that she may think that she messed up, which is totally understandable. It was a hard decision for the couple then, and it must be even harder in hindsight because of all of the success that Catelynn and Tyler have had since the show first aired. It must feel really unfair to Catelynn that she is able to give Nova so much when she was able to give Carlie so little (although, to be fair, Carlieâ€™s parents seem like theyâ€™re doing a really great job; theyâ€™re just not Catelynn.) First, Farrah informs Michael that he hung up the â€œopenâ€ sign too early, which is unprofessional (not really, the place isnâ€™t hopping or anything) and then, when he tries to explain that he had a huge mess the day before which he cleans up, she tells him that she doesnâ€™t need to hear about it because of bad vibes and negativity. â€œThere. is. no. mess.â€ she says in the tone I imagine the interrogator in 1984 used when getting ready to torture the protagonist. If Farrah doesnâ€™t believe thereâ€™s a mess then no mess ever existed, and besides, she has to go â€œpublic speak,â€ and no one should be bothering her with business concerns only hours before she appears at a â€œsummitâ€ to discuss her businesses. Thatâ€™s tip #1, aspiring entrepreneurs: Make your own reality and then punish anyone that doesnâ€™t agree with it. Michael says he wishes he could go see Farrah speak, but she says she prefers him to stay in the yogurt shop (which is a sound business decision as he is her only employee). It turns out that heâ€™s not just a simple yogurt dispenser and cashier, though. Michael is also Farrahâ€™s consultant (she asks him whether she should wear novelty glasses that advertise her business throughout her entire speech) as well as her personal assistant (she has him answer her phone and talk to Simon while she listens in, pretending that she is tied up with important business things and cannot speak to him). Farrahâ€™s dad is basically Cinderella, except he doesnâ€™t have a fairy godmother who will take over his job and let him see Farrah talk about being a titan of industry. (In this situation, the fairy godmother would be Debra, dressed in her DEBZ OG music video outfit. She wouldnâ€™t actually grant wishes, but sheâ€™d appear in a puff of cigarette smoke and rap her song until the police were called.) (Actually, that just sounds like Debra on a Tuesday.) Advertisement - Continue Reading Below At the summit, Farrah is in full â€œbusinessâ€ mode. In response to a simple â€œhelloâ€ she says sheâ€™s delighted to see so many entrepreneurs in the audience. When asked about her passions, she says that she loves food, fashion, and furnishings, which are all different in their own way. She explains that, as a mom (and a woman who went to school for restaurants), she knew she had to get into the frozen yogurt business because she could do it better than anyone else and she tells the assembled audience that sheâ€™s opened three businesses in the past six months, which sounds like the worst kind of business advice (the poor moderator is white-knuckling this thing) and that everyone with the right spirit could do the same. Well, as long as they were on Teen Mom and then also had a book written for them and also got paid for a sex tape or something. Just, you know, follow your heart. Farrah says sheâ€™s open to answer questions after sheâ€™s done speaking, but the only person who seems to be interested in her business is a blogger from Elite Daily with whom Farrah connects over the fact that the blogger is Egyptian (just like Simon!). Where is Farrah going next? Probably to Los Angeles. San Diego is all well and good, she says, but LA is where she can really get some work done. Question one: What kind of work? Is Farrah planning on opening another furniture store or a frozen yogurt location in a city thatâ€™s choked with them? Question two: Wouldnâ€™t it make more sense, as a businesswoman who has just opened three businesses in six months, to stay close by and monitor how theyâ€™re doing before expanding? It seems impossible that her ventures in an already crowded market have shown profits in such a short time and it seems like a good idea to be focusing on what she already has instead of throwing her money into more businesses. But donâ€™t take my word for it. Iâ€™m just some dude with conservative ideas. Farrahâ€™s the one who was invited to be an expert on a panel for businesspeople. And you donâ€™t get rich by not taking giant risks that make no logical sense. (Oh, what? You do? Whoâ€™s going to tell Farrah?) Follow Mark on Twitter and Cosmo Celeb on Facebook. Skip to content MilTech PR Distribution Menu HOME Add the press release Our team & Contact Posted on 30 May 2017 by Maciej Heyman 4 High-Yield Stocks to Sell Before Summer Starts Shutterstock photo By Brett Owens Sometimes itâ€™s best to sell in May and just stay away . Especially when a firmâ€™s dividend stream is being eaten alive by Amazon & Co. The Wall Street Journalâ€™s Mark Hulbert studied the â€žsummer rally mythâ€ last year â€“ and concluded it is indeed a good time to sell: â€žOver the past 60 years, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has produced an average monthly return of just 0.1% during these three summer months, compared with a 0.7% average for all other months.â€ Worse, even skilled market timers donâ€™t have much to work with. Hulbert found that over the past 60 years, rallies from Juneâ€™s lows into highs over the next two months averaged 6.9% â€“ the third-lowest such rally potential, behind (you guessed it) July and August. So should we buy these names back in September? For this disastrous four, just sell and stay away. Target ( TGT ) Dividend Yield: 4.3% Big-box retailer Target ( TGT ) has lost roughly a third of its value since 2016, and unfortunately, thereâ€™s no single thing to pin it on â€“ and thus no single quick fix. The company is throwing things against the wall to see what will stick, introducing new brands and expanding its small-format stores while trying to squeeze more sales out of its website. But Target still is struggling to get customers through the door â€“ something GlobalData Managing Director Neil Saunders says â€žis getting worse over time, especially among younger millennial consumers.â€ Whether Target can do it remains to be seen, but itâ€™s swimming upstream against Amazon.com ( AMZN ) and the growing sprawl of e-commerce, including an increasingly feisty Walmart ( WMT ) . And your reward for holding on while Target tries to successfully execute a turnaround strategy? A risky 4.3%. You can find surer retailers and higher dividend payers. Donâ€™t wait up for Target. Has Target ( TGT ) Peaked? FirstEnergy ( FE ) Dividend Yield: 5.1% When you think utilities, a few words come to mind: â€žStability.â€ â€žDividends.â€ â€žBankruptcyâ€ shouldnâ€™t be one of them. Thatâ€™s a word increasingly being floated about concerning Ohio-based utility FirstEnergy ( FE ) , however, which is among the riskiest plays in the sector right now. Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis report author Cathy Kunkel says that six of FirstEnergyâ€™s coal and nuclear plants are at risk . â€žIn the fourth quarter of 2016, FES took an $8 billion loss to write down the value of its remaining coal and nuclear units â€” an acknowledgment that FESâ€™s coal and nuclear plants have lost 88 percent and 90 percent of their value, respectively,â€ she said. Worse: FirstEnergy seems to agree with much of the IEEFAâ€™s analysis of the companyâ€™s difficulties. The analyst community is becoming bearish, too, with Christopher Turnure recently dropping FEâ€™s price target and downgrading the stock to â€žNeutralâ€ over its exit of the merchant business. Utility stocks are supposed to generate income, not headlines. Donâ€™t risk FirstEnergy going nuclear â€“ get out. FirstEnergy ( FE ) Is an Absolute Dog Macyâ€™s ( M ) Dividend Yield: 6.6% The situation at Macyâ€™s ( M ) is bad. Macyâ€™s shares are off by roughly two-thirds since 2015, because Macyâ€™s operations are in terminal decline. Revenues have dropped for two straight years, income is off roughly 25% since 2013 alone and Macyâ€™s is, ahem, â€žstreamliningâ€ its store portfolio by 100 locations. In other words, these Macyâ€™s locations are performing so poorly, itâ€™s not worth it to keep the lights on anymore. Weâ€™re now getting to the point where Macyâ€™s is being pressured to spin off its real estate as a REIT, and buyout rumors are starting to pop up, like the Hudsonâ€™s Bay talks that quickly unraveled. Thatâ€™s great if it happens, but for now, Macyâ€™s has to survive on the merit of its own business, and that business is deteriorating, as Q1â€™s big earnings and sales misses verified. The clincher? Macyâ€™s, which regularly sends out a press release dedicated to its quarterly dividend â€“ whether itâ€™s â€ Macyâ€™s, Inc. Board Declares Quarterly Dividend â€ or â€žMacyâ€™s, Inc. Increases Share Repurchase Authorization by $1.5 Billion, Declares Regular April Dividend and Announces Intent to Increase July Dividendâ€ â€“ did no such thing this quarter. Instead, its dividend declaration was slipped quietly into its first-quarter earnings release. Why? Because Macyâ€™s didnâ€™t want to draw attention to the fact that instead of boosting its dividend like it usually does this time each year, it kept the payout flat at 37.75 cents per share. Dividend growth has stopped. Letâ€™s stop pretending Macyâ€™s is going to turn this around anytime soon. If Youâ€™re Not Growing, Youâ€™re Dying, And Macyâ€™s ( M ) â€¦ Well â€¦ Annaly Capital Management (NLY) Dividend Yield: 10.3% Whatâ€™s not to like about Annaly Capital Management (NLY) ? The mortgage real estate investment trust (mREIT) sports a yield in the double digits, and itâ€™s actually beating the market so far this year with a robust 17% charge higher, putting it at levels last seen in 2014. Well â€¦ Annalyâ€™s run now has it trading at a premium to book value, so at the very least, it doesnâ€™t make sense to buy here if youâ€™re a bargain hunter. In fact, its P/B now sits at multiyear highs. But also troubling were recent first-quarter earnings, which werenâ€™t enough to cover its dividend of 30 cents per share. More worrisome is the companyâ€™s switch to core EPS, which will provide a more accurate look at how NLY is performing, but also could be more volatile amid interest-rate changes. While last yearâ€™s Q4 saw a nice one-time bump, core earnings for Q1 of this year dropped to 29 cents per share â€“ not even enough to cover the 30-cent dividend. Annalyâ€™s fundamental weakness and big year-to-date run are the perfect setup for a summer slump should the market throw a fit. This 10% yielder is a trouble just waiting to happen. Annaly (NLY) Is Hot, But Donâ€™t Get Burned! The Retirement Portfolio You NEVER Have to Touch! What good is a 4%, 7% or even 10% annual dividend yield if youâ€™re racking up similar losses or worse? You need to be averaging roughly 8% in overall annual returns, which means any investments that are treading water or losing ground are literally setting back your retirement timetable, sometimes by entire years! If you want to retire comfortably, you need a multi-tooled portfolio that not only offers big headline yield, but also dividend growth and the potential for capital gains, too! And you can find these kinds of â€žtriple threatâ€ stocks in my â€žNo Withdrawalâ€ retirement portfolio . Iâ€™ve spent months researching high-yield stocks looking for the ultimate dividend plays that deliver everything we need to build a successful retirement portfolio. I had to weed out numerous yield traps like some of the losers we mentioned above, but it was worth it, because it resulted in this canâ€™t-miss portfolio featuring: No-doubt 6%, 7% even 8% yields â€“ and in a couple of cases, double-digit dividends! I shudder when I think of some of the mediocre stocks festering in most retirement portfolios. Yes, no-growth blue chips that yield 3%, maybe 4%, might keep you from losing money, but theyâ€™ll also keep your retirement stuck in neutral! Think about it: Even if youâ€™ve saved up $500,000 for retirement, 4% annually is just $20,000 a year. You and I both know that even with Social Security tucked in there, thatâ€™s a skimpy retirement. Youâ€™ll get the names, tickers, buy prices and full analysis of their wealth-building potential! Updated: May 30, 2017 @ 11:53 pm Full Forecast News Sports Business Go! Life Buy/Sell Business Close The Associated Press This Sept. 6, 2012, file photo shows the Amazon logo in Santa Monica, Calif. Â  (AP Photo/Reed Saxon, File) Amazonâ€™s stock crosses $1,000 mark amid Wall Street love fes Seattle Times 12 hrs ago (â€¦) The Associated Press This Sept. 6, 2012, file photo shows the Amazon logo in Santa Monica, Calif. Â  (AP Photo/Reed Saxon, File) Updated at 5:30 p.m. SEATTLE â€¢ Amazon shares hit $1,000 in early Tuesday trading, reaching a numeric milestone reflecting Wall Streetâ€™s strong embrace of the e-commerce giant, something that not long ago, would have been hard to fathom. The ascension to four figures caps a somewhat jittery but ultimately triumphant two-decade run-up that started when the company went public 20 years ago. When accounting for past splits, it marks a staggering 66,567 percent rise in the value of an Amazon share since the 1997 initial public offering â€” and a 40 percent surge from last year. Amazonâ€™s stock price surged to $1,000.68 in the first-half hour of trading Tuesday. It slipped quickly from that milestone, and though it bounced back near $1,000 at midday, the stock closed the session at $996.70. To be sure, thereâ€™s nothing intrinsically magical about a $1,000 share price, even though itâ€™s rare. (According to The Associated Press, only four other U.S.-listed companies have traded above that mark.) Itâ€™s due, in part, to Amazonâ€™s reluctance to split its stock in recent years. But the number has other connotations. â€œTechnically, itâ€™s just four digits instead of three,â€ said Colin Sebastian, an analyst with R.W. Baird. â€œSymbolically, $1,000 is a demonstration of what Amazon has achieved over the last decade.â€ Thatâ€™s especially true for a company that some industry watchers doubted would make it into the mid-2000s. As recently as 2014, Amazon shares were in a relative lull, held back by widespread doubts about the companyâ€™s ability to turn a buck as it focused on growing sales. Meet the top midsized workplaces in St. Louis Public pay: Compare government and teacher salaries for St. Louis area Get the Bottom Line from Nicklaus and Gallagher How do they stack up? Compare pay of top St. Louis executives â€œAnd here we are, as perhaps one of the most dominant retail and tech companies on the planet,â€ Sebastian said. Many investors had been frustrated at times by Amazonâ€™s tendency to reinvest its cash into more employees, more warehouses and more experimental businesses. The unpredictability of the companyâ€™s quarterly earnings reports (a result, in part, of the vague guidance it gave beforehand) also yielded significant volatility to the stock price. A big shift in investorsâ€™ perception of Amazon took place in April 2015, when the company for the first time broke out the financial results of its cloud computing business. Those showed that Amazon Web Services, as the unit is called, had brought home an unexpectedly large $4.6 billion in revenue the previous year, at a profit rate that was much higher than the retail side. Another big shift took place a year ago, when analysts with Bernstein put a $1,000 price target on Amazon shares, which at the time were trading around $680. That was far higher than the street consensus of what Amazon was worth, but the analysts argued that Amazonâ€™s various businesses were so large that it would be hard for the company to keep throwing most of its profits back into investments. Even a $1,000 stock price wouldnâ€™t account in the long term for the value being generated by the giant Seattle company, the analysts concluded. Skip to content MilTech PR Distribution Menu HOME Add the press release Our team & Contact Posted on 30 May 2017 by Maciej Heyman FTC Sends Additional Refund Checks Totaling Almost $2 Million to People Who Bought Green Coffee Weight-Loss Supplements The Federal Trade Commission is mailing 38,553 refund checks totaling $1.9 million to people who bought Pure Health or Genesis Today green coffee bean extract supplements from retailers such as Walmart. This is the second refund mailing related to this FTC case. In June 2016, the FTC used the defendantsâ€™ sales records to mail full refunds to nearly 200,000 people who bought the products online. When the first checks were mailed, the FTC announced a claims process for people who bought the supplements in retail stores. People who submitted valid claims before the deadline are now receiving full refunds, averaging $49.66 each. Recipients should deposit or cash their checks within 60 days. The FTCâ€™s January 2015 complaint charged Pure Health LLC, Genesis Today, Inc., and their principal, Lindsey Duncan, with deceptively claiming that the supplement would cause people to lose 17 pounds and 16 percent of their body fat in just 12 weeks without diet or exercise, and that the claim was backed up by a clinical study. The FTCâ€™s settlement barred the defendants from making deceptive weight-loss claims about any food or dietary supplement, and required them to pay money for the refund program. Analytics, the refund administrator for this matter, will begin mailing refund checks today. If you have questions, please call 1-844-449-3586. To learn more about the FTCâ€™s refund program, visit www.ftc.gov/refunds. The Federal Trade Commission works to promote competition, and protect and educate consumers. You can learn more about consumer topics and file a consumer complaint online or by calling 1-877-FTC-HELP (382-4357). Like the FTC on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, read our blogs and subscribe to press releases for the latest FTC news and resources. Skip to content MilTech PR Distribution Menu HOME Add the press release Our team & Contact Posted on 30 May 2017 by Maciej Heyman 4 High-Yield Stocks to Sell Before Summer Starts Shutterstock photo By Brett Owens Sometimes itâ€™s best to sell in May and just stay away . Especially when a firmâ€™s dividend stream is being eaten alive by Amazon & Co. The Wall Street Journalâ€™s Mark Hulbert studied the â€žsummer rally mythâ€ last year â€“ and concluded it is indeed a good time to sell: â€žOver the past 60 years, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has produced an average monthly return of just 0.1% during these three summer months, compared with a 0.7% average for all other months.â€ Worse, even skilled market timers donâ€™t have much to work with. Hulbert found that over the past 60 years, rallies from Juneâ€™s lows into highs over the next two months averaged 6.9% â€“ the third-lowest such rally potential, behind (you guessed it) July and August. So should we buy these names back in September? For this disastrous four, just sell and stay away. Target ( TGT ) Dividend Yield: 4.3% Big-box retailer Target ( TGT ) has lost roughly a third of its value since 2016, and unfortunately, thereâ€™s no single thing to pin it on â€“ and thus no single quick fix. The company is throwing things against the wall to see what will stick, introducing new brands and expanding its small-format stores while trying to squeeze more sales out of its website. But Target still is struggling to get customers through the door â€“ something GlobalData Managing Director Neil Saunders says â€žis getting worse over time, especially among younger millennial consumers.â€ Whether Target can do it remains to be seen, but itâ€™s swimming upstream against Amazon.com ( AMZN ) and the growing sprawl of e-commerce, including an increasingly feisty Walmart ( WMT ) . And your reward for holding on while Target tries to successfully execute a turnaround strategy? A risky 4.3%. You can find surer retailers and higher dividend payers. Donâ€™t wait up for Target. Has Target ( TGT ) Peaked? FirstEnergy ( FE ) Dividend Yield: 5.1% When you think utilities, a few words come to mind: â€žStability.â€ â€žDividends.â€ â€žBankruptcyâ€ shouldnâ€™t be one of them. Thatâ€™s a word increasingly being floated about concerning Ohio-based utility FirstEnergy ( FE ) , however, which is among the riskiest plays in the sector right now. Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis report author Cathy Kunkel says that six of FirstEnergyâ€™s coal and nuclear plants are at risk . â€žIn the fourth quarter of 2016, FES took an $8 billion loss to write down the value of its remaining coal and nuclear units â€” an acknowledgment that FESâ€™s coal and nuclear plants have lost 88 percent and 90 percent of their value, respectively,â€ she said. Worse: FirstEnergy seems to agree with much of the IEEFAâ€™s analysis of the companyâ€™s difficulties. The analyst community is becoming bearish, too, with Christopher Turnure recently dropping FEâ€™s price target and downgrading the stock to â€žNeutralâ€ over its exit of the merchant business. Utility stocks are supposed to generate income, not headlines. Donâ€™t risk FirstEnergy going nuclear â€“ get out. FirstEnergy ( FE ) Is an Absolute Dog Macyâ€™s ( M ) Dividend Yield: 6.6% The situation at Macyâ€™s ( M ) is bad. Macyâ€™s shares are off by roughly two-thirds since 2015, because Macyâ€™s operations are in terminal decline. Revenues have dropped for two straight years, income is off roughly 25% since 2013 alone and Macyâ€™s is, ahem, â€žstreamliningâ€ its store portfolio by 100 locations. In other words, these Macyâ€™s locations are performing so poorly, itâ€™s not worth it to keep the lights on anymore. Weâ€™re now getting to the point where Macyâ€™s is being pressured to spin off its real estate as a REIT, and buyout rumors are starting to pop up, like the Hudsonâ€™s Bay talks that quickly unraveled. Thatâ€™s great if it happens, but for now, Macyâ€™s has to survive on the merit of its own business, and that business is deteriorating, as Q1â€™s big earnings and sales misses verified. The clincher? Macyâ€™s, which regularly sends out a press release dedicated to its quarterly dividend â€“ whether itâ€™s â€ Macyâ€™s, Inc. Board Declares Quarterly Dividend â€ or â€žMacyâ€™s, Inc. Increases Share Repurchase Authorization by $1.5 Billion, Declares Regular April Dividend and Announces Intent to Increase July Dividendâ€ â€“ did no such thing this quarter. Instead, its dividend declaration was slipped quietly into its first-quarter earnings release. Why? Because Macyâ€™s didnâ€™t want to draw attention to the fact that instead of boosting its dividend like it usually does this time each year, it kept the payout flat at 37.75 cents per share. Dividend growth has stopped. Letâ€™s stop pretending Macyâ€™s is going to turn this around anytime soon. If Youâ€™re Not Growing, Youâ€™re Dying, And Macyâ€™s ( M ) â€¦ Well â€¦ Annaly Capital Management (NLY) Dividend Yield: 10.3% Whatâ€™s not to like about Annaly Capital Management (NLY) ? The mortgage real estate investment trust (mREIT) sports a yield in the double digits, and itâ€™s actually beating the market so far this year with a robust 17% charge higher, putting it at levels last seen in 2014. Well â€¦ Annalyâ€™s run now has it trading at a premium to book value, so at the very least, it doesnâ€™t make sense to buy here if youâ€™re a bargain hunter. In fact, its P/B now sits at multiyear highs. But also troubling were recent first-quarter earnings, which werenâ€™t enough to cover its dividend of 30 cents per share. More worrisome is the companyâ€™s switch to core EPS, which will provide a more accurate look at how NLY is performing, but also could be more volatile amid interest-rate changes. While last yearâ€™s Q4 saw a nice one-time bump, core earnings for Q1 of this year dropped to 29 cents per share â€“ not even enough to cover the 30-cent dividend. Annalyâ€™s fundamental weakness and big year-to-date run are the perfect setup for a summer slump should the market throw a fit. This 10% yielder is a trouble just waiting to happen. Annaly (NLY) Is Hot, But Donâ€™t Get Burned! The Retirement Portfolio You NEVER Have to Touch! What good is a 4%, 7% or even 10% annual dividend yield if youâ€™re racking up similar losses or worse? You need to be averaging roughly 8% in overall annual returns, which means any investments that are treading water or losing ground are literally setting back your retirement timetable, sometimes by entire years! If you want to retire comfortably, you need a multi-tooled portfolio that not only offers big headline yield, but also dividend growth and the potential for capital gains, too! And you can find these kinds of â€žtriple threatâ€ stocks in my â€žNo Withdrawalâ€ retirement portfolio . Iâ€™ve spent months researching high-yield stocks looking for the ultimate dividend plays that deliver everything we need to build a successful retirement portfolio. I had to weed out numerous yield traps like some of the losers we mentioned above, but it was worth it, because it resulted in this canâ€™t-miss portfolio featuring: No-doubt 6%, 7% even 8% yields â€“ and in a couple of cases, double-digit dividends! The potential for 7% to 15% in annual capital gains Robust dividend growth that will keep up with (and beat) inflation These are the three most critical elements for any retirement portfolio, because achieving all three allows you to live off income alone while actually growing your nest egg . I shudder when I think of some of the mediocre stocks festering in most retirement portfolios. Yes, no-growth blue chips that yield 3%, maybe 4%, might keep you from losing money, but theyâ€™ll also keep your retirement stuck in neutral! Think about it: Even if youâ€™ve saved up $500,000 for retirement, 4% annually is just $20,000 a year. You and I both know that even with Social Security tucked in there, thatâ€™s a skimpy retirement. My â€žNo Withdrawalâ€ portfolio averages 8% across the board right now, and offers dividend growth that will result in double-digit â€žyields on costâ€ over time. That will ensure you have every cent of income so you can pay the bills and have plenty left over to actually enjoy your retirement years. Meanwhile, the growth potential of these picks will help grow your nest egg, which is essential should you ever need to pay for a big one-time expense, whether itâ€™s an emergency or just buying a vacation home. This all-star portfolio features the absolute best of several high-income assets, from preferred stocks to REITs to closed-end funds and more. That means diversification and continued payouts regardless of how volatile or bearish the stock market becomes. Donâ€™t let mediocre yields from uninspired, lazy stock picks ruin the retirement youâ€™ve worked so hard to build. You deserve substantial, regular dividend checks that will let you see the world and live in comfort for the rest of your post-career life. Let me show you the path to a no-worry retirement. To: Required Needs to be a valid email From: Required Needs to be a valid email Subject: 4 Dividend Aristocrats Warren Buffett Owns Message: URL: https://mney.co/2qxB2Kh eight Â Ã—Â  eight Â =Â  Required Please enter the correct value. Share Email this Article Send with mail | ahoo instead. To: Required Needs to be a valid email From: Required Needs to be a valid email Subject: 4 Dividend Aristocrats Warren Buffett Owns Message: URL: https://mney.co/2qxB2Kh Â Ã—Â  5 Â =Â  five Required Please enter the correct value. get daily headlines subscribe now! today's private briefing Access Your Profit Alerts Twitter no responses Stocks 4 Dividend Aristocrats Warren Buffett Owns By Jack Delaney, Associate Editor, Money Morning â€¢ May 30, 2017 Start the conversation Leave a Reply Click here to cancel reply. Your email address will not be published. Required fields are marked * Comment Some HTML is OK Sign me up for the Money Morning newsletter Name * Email * Website nine Â +Â  four Â =Â  Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (NYSE: BRK.A) doesn't pay a dividend, but the company and the stock both benefit greatly from owning shares of some of the best dividend aristocrats on the market. CEO Warren BuffettÂ has told investors about the power of compounding interest for decades and referenced it in a 1964 letter to his partners. At the time, he said an investment may start off paying just a few percentage points. For example, PepsiCo Inc. (NYSE: PEP) pays a dividend of $0.81 per share, which is a yield of 2.81%. If you bought $10,000 shares of PEP on May 1, 2016, and reinvested the dividends through a dividend reinvestment program (DRIP), your shares would have been worth $11,172 on May 1, 2017. What Is a Dividend Aristocrat? Dividend aristocrats are companies that have increased their dividend payments for 25 consecutive years. Some of the most well-known dividend aristocrats include: Exxon Mobil Corp. (NYSE: XOM) pays a dividend of $0.77, which is a yield of 3.75%. Aflac Inc. (NYSE: AFL) pays a dividend of $0.43, which is a yield of 2.32%. AT&T Inc. (NYSE: T) pays a dividend of $0.49, which is a yield of 5.12%. T-Rowe Price Group Inc. (Nasdaq: TROW) pays a dividend of $0.57, which is a yield of 3.27%. Clorox Co. (NYSE: CLX) pays a dividend of $0.84, which is a yield of 2.50%. If you just kept the dividends, your investment would be worth $11,147. That's a difference of only $25. So it may not seem like a big deal at first glance. However, Buffett said in that 1964 letter that the power of compounding interest "mushrooms" over time. According to its website, Pepsi first paid a dividend on Feb. 1, 2001. If you invested $10,000 and reinvested the dividends since then, your shares would have been worth $34,390 on Feb. 1, 2017, according to DividendChannel.com. That's an annual average return of 8.02%. In comparison, an index fund that tracked the S&P 500 would have made just $22,007, for an average annual return of just 5.05%. So you'd have an extra $12,383 in your pocket just from sitting by and having your dividends automatically reinvested for you. Trending Story: The 7 Best Dividend Stocks to Buy in 2017 Best of all, this is a passive investment strategy that doesn't involve timing the market or making risky decisions. And because compounding interest is so powerful, I wanted to dig through Buffett's portfolio of dividend stocks, especially the dividend aristocrats. I wanted Money Morning readers to know exactly what's in Buffett's portfolio. Buffett currently has four dividend aristocrats in his portfolio, and one stands out above the rest. Here are the four dividend aristocrats in Buffet's portfolio, including the best of the bunchâ€¦ Dividend Aristocrat No. 4: The Coca-Cola Co. According to Fortune, Buffett drinks five 12-ounce cans of Coke a day. He likes the company so much that The Coca-Cola Co. (NYSE: KO) is Berkshire's 12th-largest holding. According to its website, Coke has paid a quarterly dividend since 1920 and has increased dividend payments in each of the last 55 years. Today, KO pays shareholders a dividend of $0.37, for a yield of 3.29%. The billionaire zeroed in on KO stock because of its strong business and because of the 1987 stock market crash. Coca-Cola is and was the most well-known soda maker, and Buffett believed the stock was being undervalued at the time. According to Investopedia.com, Buffett purchased more than $1 billion of Coca-Cola stock in 1988, which made him a 6.2% owner of the company. In the beginning of that year, KO shares opened at $2.39 on Jan. 4, 1998. Video U.S. Becoming Warren Buffett On May 24, 2017, shares of KO opened at $44.51. That's an increase of 1,762% in 29 years. Now, Buffett has a 9.32% stake in the company, and his shares of KO are worth $2.2 billion. Dividend Aristocrat No. 3: Procter & Gamble Co. Buffett owned roughly $4 billion in Procter & Gamble Co. (NYSE: PG) in May 2016, although his stake in the company was not through direct stock purchases. In 1989, Buffett invested $600 million in razor-blade giant Gillette, which gave Berkshire an 11% stake in the company. Like Coca-Cola, razor blades are a product consumers buy no matter what is happening with the company or the market. Sales will always be steady, and this fits Buffett's strategy of investing in what he understands. However, this was an even more profitable investment than Buffett could have originally imagined. Procter &Â Gamble announced in January 2005 that it would acquire Gillette, which valued Buffett's shares at roughly $5 billion. At the time, the PG stock price was trading at $54.50 per share. On May 24, 2017, the PG stock price opened at $86.45. In 12 years, that's a small increase of 58.62%. However, the dividend has drastically increased since Procter first paid shareholders $0.05 per share in 1990. Today, PG pays a dividend of $0.69, which is a yield of 3.19%. That's an increase of 1,280% over 27 years. He then exchanged most of his PG shares in 2014 when it was trading for roughly $90 per share for ownership of Procter's Duracell battery division. As of Q1 2017, Berkshire has $27.1 million worth of PG stock in its portfolio. Dividend Aristocrat No. 2: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. Buffett first bought shares of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (NYSE: WMT) in 2005. WMT shares traded at roughly $50 per share at the time. Today, Wal-Mart stock trades for $78.56 per share, which is a small increase of 57.12%. But the real wealth builder from WMT stock has been the annual increase in its dividend payout. If you purchased $10,000 worth of WMT stock in 1995, reinvested the dividend, and sold it 20 years later, your WMT shares would be worth $86,437. In comparison, an investment in a fund that tracks the S&P 500 would be worth $50,395, according to DividendChannel.com. Again, that's an extra $36,042 in your pocket with almost no upfront work at all. The WMT dividend payout has increased annually every year since it first paid $0.05 per share in March 1974. Today, the retailer pays $0.51 per share, which is a yield of 2.61%. That's a 920% increase over 43 years. But the dividend payout wasn't good enough to keep Buffett aroundâ€¦ According to Fortune, Buffett's shares of WMT were worth $3 billion in the summer of 2016, and Berkshire sold most of its shares in Q4 2016. The company unloaded almost $900 million worth of WMT and now holds just $109.5 million. The reason? Buffett saw the shift in how consumers buy products, using online platforms instead of shopping in stores. At Berkshire's annual meeting in 2016, he reportedly said Amazon.com Inc. (Nasdaq: AMZN) is a "big force" and that other companies have not figured out how to counter or effectively participate in online selling. Buffett's sell-off of WMT shows even if a company pays a dividend, the stock isn't always worth owning. However, we do have a new profit opportunity from one dividend aristocrat in Buffett's portfolio. And according Money Morning Director of Tech & Venture Capital Research Michael A. Robinson, this dividend-paying stock should be a foundational holding for our readersâ€¦ Join the conversation. Click here to jump to commentsâ€¦ (0) COMMENTS FACEBOOK COMMENTS TAGS Tags: Dividends Leave a Reply Click here to cancel reply. Your email address will not be published. Select Topics & Save Latest News May 30, 2017 â€¢ By Money Morning Staff Reports Leave a Comment THAAD Can't Protect American and South Korean Lives May 30, 2017 â€¢ By Garrett Baldwin Leave a Comment Dow Jones News Today: Stocks Down as President Trump Feuds with Chancellor Angela Merkel May 30, 2017 â€¢ By Dustin Parrett Leave a Comment What Is the Master Settlement Agreement? So everyone's wondering how stocks are going up. Brian McGairty, on May 30 at approximately 4:30 a.m., four menÂ entered Walmart in Pearl and went to the electronics department. They went behind the glass container that holds electronics like tablets and cellphones. An employee saw them behind the counter and asked what they were doing. The men displayed hammers and threatened the employee that they would hit her if she came closer. The men broke the glass container with their hammers and stole cell phones and tablets before running out the back of the building.Â  The four were seen leaving the scene in a silver Chrysler 300 with no tag.Â  The case is being investigated as an armed robbery.Â  Additional information will be made available as the case unfolds. Hopefully surveillance and images will be out later today.Â  Copyright 2017Â MSNewsNow.Â All rights reserved. Please turn Javascript on to get the best experience from rte.ie News Sport Entertainment Business Lifestyle Culture Player TV Radio More Today 17Â° to 21Â° Tonight 11Â° to 12Â° Go Weather Aertel Watch Live Lotto Jobs Apps RTÃ‰ Archives Century Ireland Gaeilge RTÃ‰ Orchestras RTÃ‰ Shop Â  TRTÃ‰ RTÃ‰ Jr About RTÃ‰ Blog News Business Brexit Bites Technology Markets Economy Analysis Amazon shares rise above $1,000 for the first time Updated / Tuesday, 30 May 2017 16:34 Amazon's market capitalisation stands at about $478 billion Shares of Amazon surged above $1,000 for the first time today, marking another milestone in the rise of the American online retail giant. Amazon's market capitalisation stood at about $478 billion, more than twice that of Wal-Mart Stores. After going in public in May 1997 at $18 a share, Amazon has benefited from tectonic shifts in US technology and consumer shopping habits that are expected to continue to remake the retail industry.Â  The company has evolved from its origins as an online bookseller into a broad-based retailer of apparel and household staples, from electronics to sausage casing.Â  With its "Prime" subscription service, it also has become a creative force in Hollywood and beyond.Â  Amazon shares have appreciated especially rapidly over the last three years in anticipation that e-commerce will become a much bigger force in the retail sector. Â  Online sales currently comprise about 8% of the US retail market. Amazon alone accounts for about 43% of US online sales, according to consultancy Slice Intelligence.Â  E-commerce is expected to grow between 8-12% this year, according to the National Retail Federation, about three times as much as the rest of the industry, which has faced massive store and mall closures.Â  Amazon, whose revenues grew to $35.7 billion in the first quarter, also has impressed Wall Street by laying out a plan to achieve greater profitability.Â  It is in the process of investing $1.5 billion to establish its own delivery network and lessen its dependence on shipping giants FedEx and UPS.Â  That will help contain delivery costs, which grew 30% to $1.9 billion in the first quarter. The surge above $1,000 a share also raises questions about whether Amazon intends to pursue a stock split.Â  At Amazon's annual meeting a week ago, chief executive Jeff Bezos said the matter was under consideration. The company had three previous stock splits, in June 1998 and in January and August 1999. Amazon currently is the fourth biggest company by market capitalisation after Apple, Google's parent Alphabet and Microsoft. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer) NEW YORK (AP) â€” Amazon, the internet goliath that revolutionized the way much of the world buys books, toilet paper and TVs, hit a new milestone Tuesday. Its stock surpassed the $1,000 mark for the first time. That price put Amazon's market value at about $478 billion, double that of the world's biggest traditional retailer, Wal-Mart, and more than 15 times the size of Target. A $1,000 investment on Amazon's first day of trading in 1997 would be worth more than $500,000 today. Not only has Amazon changed the retail landscape since it became a public company 20 years ago, it's now part of a small cadre of high-flying stocks belonging to companies that have defied Wall Street and shunned stock splits. Those splits make the stock more affordable and generate brokerage fees. But companies like Amazon have chosen to reward its long-term investors. The last time Amazon has split its stock was nearly 18 years ago, according to financial research firm FactSet. Another company with a similar philosophy is Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. Amazon just beat Alphabet to the $1,000 level, with its Class A shares just $2 short of $1,000 Tuesday. Only four other U.S.-listed companies have shares trading above $1,000: online travel booking company Priceline Group Inc., homebuilder NVR Inc., pork producer and ocean transportation company Seaboard Corp. and the apostle of long-term investing, Warren Buffett, with his holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. But stock prices only tell a part of the story. The value of a company is determined by its stock price and the number of shares on the market. Amazon.com is well over four times the size of Priceline, NVR and Seaboard combined. It's 17 percent bigger than Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate with ownership stakes in some of America's most well-known consumer brands like Coca-Cola, insurance companies and U.S. infrastructure. Since launching a website to sell mostly books in 1995, Amazon has transfigured retail, sent revenue numbers to stratospheric heights, and is among the biggest reasons longtime powerhouses like Macy's, Borders bookstores and even RadioShack have suffered. Get breaking news sent instantly to your inbox Sign Up! I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site consitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. Those companies are closing locations and Amazon is filling the void, sometimes literally. Last week in a location once occupied by Borders, the bookstore chain that went out of business in 2011, Amazon opened its first bookstore in New York City. _____ Contact Joseph Pisani at http://twitter.com/josephpisani Copyright 2017 The Associated Press. Poll: Most disapprove of ObamaCare repeal efforts Healthcare â€” 0s ago 'Covfefe' trends on social media after Trump shares unfinished tweet with typo Blog Briefing Room â€” 2h 14m ago Social media reacts to report Trump gave cell number to foreign leaders In The Know â€” 3h 37m ago House Intel Dem fires back at Nunes over Russia probe remarks House â€” 3h 58m ago CNN 'evaluating' Kathy Griffin's NYE role: 'No decisions at this point' Blog Briefing Room â€” 4h 42m ago Scott Pelley ousted from 'CBS Evening News' anchor role: report Blog Briefing Room â€” 4h 55m ago Trump asks world leaders to call him on his cell: report Blog Briefing Room â€” 5h 31m ago Putin echoes Trump, Nunes lines on U.S. Russia investigation Administration â€” 5h 37m ago view all Â  Companies are embracing green policies â€” Why wonâ€™t Washington? By Jeffrey Gracer, opinion contributor - 05/30/17 11:00 AM EDT 9 Â  Â© Thinkstock As a revanchist attack against environmental regulation unfolds in Washington cloaked in pro-business rhetoric, a pragmatic forward-looking revolution is taking place in financial centers and corporate boardrooms around the country, supported by leadership from state and local governments. These businesses and governments know that a dystopian future driven by unchecked greenhouse gas emissions will not be good for anyone â€” including business. They also know that deep decarbonization is not only possible but economically beneficial. Jobs are being created and profits are being made driving innovation toward a more sustainable future. ADVERTISEMENT As former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg writes in â€œClimate of Hope,â€ the evidence that this can be done is all around us and is continuing to multiply. Now more than ever, many in the private sector are defending these principles and driving them forward with a new sense of urgency. Â  Just as corporations learned decades ago that they could increase profits by reverse engineering their operations to minimize discharges of conventional pollution, businesses today are learning they can operate more profitably by reducing their carbon footprints. Companies like Anheiser Bush InBev and General Motors are saving tens of millions of dollars participating in the renewable energy (RE100) program established by The Climate Group and CDP. Walmart has proved that rooftop solar projects can be installed at scale, reducing energy costs and providing a healthy return on investment. Google is creating demand for wind and other sustainable energy projects to power their business operations and reduce costs. GE is replacing certain conventional vehicles with electric vehicles, demonstrating that lower maintenance requirements and fuel savings make these fleets highly cost-effective. Unilever is working with suppliers to source sustainably harvested products. States like California, Massachusetts and New York, and cities like San Francisco, Chicago and New York, are partnering with businesses to create new low carbon opportunities. These combined efforts are creating hundreds of thousands of high-paying jobs in agriculture, wind and solar, energy efficiency and other sectors. Many of these transformations are being fueled by a generational shift that began in the 1970s and is now in full expression. Baby boomers who grew up during an era of increased environmental awareness are todayâ€™s CEOs, CFOs and board members. The younger generations that came after them are taking environmental awareness to a new level, creating a broad and deep movement of newly-minted socially conscious innovators within the corporate world. The best and brightest graduates want to use their talents to create more responsible business practices and drive sustainable profits. They are bringing an impressive array of financial, technical and organizational skill to the table. This shift in the corporate world was visible in the climate change negotiations that culminated in the Paris Agreement. Many corporations played a constructive and critical role in support of that effort. And after the election, those same entities have been outspoken in their support of the agreement. In a time where so much seems uncertain, one can find reason for hope in these developments. With or without Washington, the work being undertaken by many members of the private sector and state and local governments will continue. Indeed, that work is likely to intensify as companies and state and local governments resist policies and regulations that would undermine their efforts. Many understandably lament the death of bipartisan support in Washington for sensible environmental regulation, including the abandonment of support for market-based mechanisms to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. But it would be wise for politicians in Washington to take note of what is happening outside of the District, where there is much greater consensus. An increasingly vocal majority of Americans of both political parties want environmental protections to endure, including many within the business community. There is surprisingly broad and deep bipartisan support for these principles. Many are prepared to defend a future for all Americans that includes protection of human health and the environment. Companies are prepared to make the case that a decarbonized economy makes good business sense. Concerned Americans are committed to doing the work necessary to achieve the transformation that will be required to get there. As the Financial Times recently reported, this â€œBig Green Bangâ€ is proving so profitable that it is unstoppable. There is reason to be hopeful that broad support for a decarbonized future will continue to grow as evidence pours in showing that companies can profit while reducing pollution. But we are running out of time. Now is the moment for cost-effective solutions to be scaled up and for increased engagement by the business community, in partnership with state and local governments. The question for Washington is why it would not also support this pro-business agenda. Jeffrey Gracer is a principal at Sive, Paget & Riesel, P.C. in New York City, the nationâ€™s first environmental law firm. He is a member of the U.S. Board of The Climate Group. The opinions expressed in this article are the authorâ€™s and do not necessarily reflect the views of the firm or its clients. Follow him on Twitter @jgracer.Â  The views expressed by contributors are their own and are not the views of The Hill.
